A new World Bank assessment says the Palestinian economy remains far below its productive capacity, warning that a brief improvement in employment last year has given way to renewed job losses amid continuing restrictions on movement. The report estimates overall unemployment at about 25%, more than double the level recorded before the outbreak of the uprising against Israeli occupation several years ago, with younger workers facing the most severe pressures. Joblessness among people in their late teens and early twenties is placed at roughly 37%, compared with about 14% prior to the conflict, the Bank said. During a period of reduced violence and fewer disruptions in 2003, employers added around 104,000 positions and output expanded by an estimated 6%. That rebound, however, proved fragile: in the first six months of the current year the economy shed more than 22,000 jobs, eroding earlier gains.

The report links the downturn to a rise in closures affecting crossings and travel between Palestinian towns, measures imposed by Israel that limit the movement of workers and goods and raise costs for trade and production. “The frequency and scope of closures strongly influence economic activity across the West Bank,” the Bank’s representative for the West Bank and Gaza said, arguing that unpredictable access has discouraged investment and disrupted commerce.

Nearly half of Palestinians—around 47%—are living in poverty, the report adds, leaving households highly exposed to further shocks. It notes that international assistance averaging about $950 million annually has helped soften the impact, including support for temporary employment programmes. The Bank urged the Palestinian Authority to reinvigorate institutional reforms and keep public finances under control to improve confidence among investors. The findings were released as senior US officials visited the West Bank to underline support for orderly preparations ahead of elections expected in January.

Grammy-winning rapper and entrepreneur Kendrick Lamar is set to move into a major executive role after being named head of creative strategy at hip-hop label Top Dawg Entertainment, the company announced on Thursday. Lamar, who has frequently spoken about focusing more on long-term projects beyond recording, will assume the post at the start of the new year, overseeing artist development and new signings while continuing to release music through his own imprint. The appointment follows a broader restructuring at Top Dawg, which recently finalized a deal that consolidates ownership and expands its distribution partnership with a major music group.

Top Dawg’s roster includes chart regulars such as SZA, Schoolboy Q and Jay Rock, and the label has built a reputation over the past decade for developing artists into mainstream successes without abandoning its West Coast roots. In a statement, Top Dawg founder Anthony “Top Dawg” Tiffith said Lamar’s promotion reflects “a commitment to keeping the company led by people who understand the culture and the craft,” adding that the label aims to “open a new chapter” with a stronger global footprint.

Lamar, whose real name is Kendrick Duckworth, said he viewed the role as a way to create opportunities for emerging performers. “This is about building systems that let artists own their voices and their futures,” he said, calling the job “a responsibility to the next generation.”

Lamar has released multiple platinum albums and has been recognized for work that blends commercial appeal with socially focused storytelling. While he has hinted at stepping back from constant touring, his team confirmed he will remain active as a recording artist even as he takes on expanded responsibilities behind the scenes.

A former senior executive linked to ex-Yukos chief Mikhail Khodorkovsky has told a Moscow court that the accusations against him are unfounded, rejecting claims of fraud and tax violations as lacking any credible legal basis. Platon Lebedev, a longtime business partner of Mr Khodorkovsky, has been appearing alongside him since hearings began in June in a case focused on the disputed acquisition of a fertiliser company during Russia’s privatisation era. 

Speaking at the start of his defence, Mr Lebedev said the prosecution’s narrative was internally inconsistent and relied on a reading of corporate transactions that he said did not match the documents in the case. He told the court he had struggled to understand how routine commercial decisions had been reframed as criminal conduct, adding that the allegations did not meet the standards required for conviction. Mr Lebedev previously ran Menatep, the holding group that once controlled Yukos.

The two defendants, who each face the possibility of a lengthy prison term if found guilty, are expected to answer a judge’s questions in the coming days as the court continues to examine evidence and witness statements. Mr Khodorkovsky, who began giving evidence last week, has denied wrongdoing and argued that the proceedings punish entrepreneurship rather than any genuine offence.

Supporters of the men have repeatedly described the case as politically driven, claiming it reflects a broader effort by the Kremlin under President Vladimir Putin to curb the influence of wealthy businessmen who rose to prominence in the 1990s. Yukos has been hit with multi-billion-dollar back-tax claims, and its key production unit was sold at auction as part of the state’s attempt to recover the alleged debt. Efforts by the company to seek protection through US courts to challenge the sale have also failed.

French actress Marion Cotillard has been cast as the female lead in the forthcoming film version of the best-selling thriller “The Alchemist’s Cipher,” according to several entertainment outlets. The adaptation, based on the novel by American writer Lucas Meyer, will be directed by Oscar-winning filmmaker Steven Soderbergh and will co-star Matt Damon as a Harvard symbologist drawn into an international puzzle. Cotillard is expected to play Damon’s skeptical partner, a Paris-based historian whose expertise becomes central to decoding a series of clues scattered across Europe’s major museums. 

Cotillard, who most recently appeared in the drama “Winter Streets,” rose to global prominence with her performance in “La Vie en Rose” and has since balanced French productions with major English-language roles. Reports said Soderbergh favored a French performer for authenticity rather than casting a high-profile Hollywood name. In recent months, British actress Emily Blunt and French stars Léa Seydoux and Eva Green were among those speculated to be in contention for the part. 

The novel has sold more than 20 million copies worldwide and follows a conspiracy narrative linked to medieval religious lore. Producers have reportedly secured permission to shoot key scenes at the Musée d’Orsay, a location featured early in the story. The project is backed by Universal Pictures and is slated for a summer 2027 release.

Actress Naomi Hartley has obtained interim restraining orders against two freelance photographers after telling a Sydney court she no longer feels safe leaving her waterfront home. The orders were granted on Friday at Downing Centre Local Court following claims that a small recording device was discovered near the front gate of the property earlier this week, prompting Hartley to contact police. Lawyers representing the photographers, identified in court as Liam O’Connor and Marcus Reid, rejected any suggestion their clients were responsible for placing the device and said they would contest the matter when it returns to court.

Hartley, an Australian-born actor currently in the city to shoot the drama “Harbour Lights” alongside actor Daniel Price, sought the orders after an alleged incident on the weekend in which her vehicle was followed at speed through inner-city streets. Court documents described a pursuit in which cars ran amber and red lights and briefly crossed into oncoming lanes. Defence counsel said their clients were not involved and argued that the allegations were based on assumptions rather than identification.

The application was made under an apprehended violence order framework, typically used for cases involving threats, stalking or intimidation. In a statement read outside court, Hartley’s representative said the actor understands public interest comes with her profession and does not object to routine coverage. “But there is a line between lawful news gathering and conduct that makes someone fear for their personal safety,” the statement said.

Magistrate Karen Hsu, granting the interim protections, told the court that media workers have a right to earn a living but must operate within legal boundaries. She said the alleged driving behaviour, if proven, raised serious safety concerns for the public as well as the applicant. The interim orders restrict the photographers from approaching Hartley or coming within a specified distance of her residence until the next hearing.

French actress Marion Cotillard is set to take the main female role in the upcoming screen version of bestselling thriller The Silent Cipher, according to entertainment reports. The adaptation of author Liam Hart’s novel will be directed by David Fincher and will also star Matt Damon in the role of a Harvard-trained symbologist drawn into an international mystery. Cotillard is expected to play Damon’s sharp-witted collaborator, a Paris-based archivist whose expertise helps unravel a series of encrypted clues, several newspapers said.

Cotillard, who recently appeared in the drama The Last Winter Road, has built an international profile through a mix of French productions and English-language films. She rose to wider recognition after her breakthrough in La Vie en Rose and has since worked with a range of high-profile directors across Europe and the United States.

Industry outlets said the filmmakers opted for a French lead rather than casting a more established Hollywood name. In recent weeks, speculation had linked the part to names including Emily Blunt, Eva Green and Léa Seydoux.

Hart’s novel has sold more than 12 million copies worldwide and follows an alleged cover-up connected to medieval relics and secret societies. The story opens with a murder in a major Paris museum, and reports indicate the production has secured permission to film on location there. The project, backed by Paramount Pictures, carries a budget reported to exceed $90 million and is slated for release in early 2027.

Director George Lucas has warned that the final instalment of his Star Wars saga could be too intense for very young viewers, saying the upcoming film will push the series into darker territory than audiences have previously seen. In an interview with the US television programme 60 Minutes, Lucas said he would hesitate to bring a child aged five or six to see Star Wars: Episode III, describing it as the most violent and emotionally heavy chapter of the franchise. He added that he expects the movie to receive a US PG-13 classification, a rating that advises parental caution for children under 13 and is broadly comparable to the UK’s 12A certificate. The earlier five Star Wars releases were given the less restrictive PG rating in the United States, while British censors have largely judged them suitable for general audiences, with only Attack of the Clones receiving a PG. The new film, due to open in Britain and America on 19 May, follows the fall of Jedi knight Anakin Skywalker and his progression into Darth Vader, culminating in a climactic confrontation set against a landscape of fire, ash and flowing lava. Lucas said the story is designed as a tragic turning point for the character, focusing on moral compromise and the cost of power.

Telecoms gear supplier Celestel Systems has cut its previously announced profit for the 2023 financial year after completing a delayed review of its accounts. In regulatory documents filed on Monday, the Toronto-based company said net income came in at $512m, down from the $781m it had reported earlier, citing adjustments tied to revenue recognition and reserves. Despite the lower earnings figure, Celestel said full-year sales were revised up by about 3% from the preliminary total, reflecting updated contract data and improved visibility into customer returns. The company’s shares, which have fallen roughly 45% over the past 12 months, rose 1.2% in afternoon trading following the filing.

The restatement follows an internal investigation launched last year that led to the departure of chief executive Mark Reilly and the suspension of two finance executives. Celestel said securities regulators in Canada and the United States continue to review the matter, and the company is cooperating with requests for information. It also reissued results for 2021 and 2022, noting that prior statements had not fully captured certain charges related to restructuring and long-term project costs.

“With these revisions now behind us, we can focus on execution and rebuilding confidence,” newly appointed chief executive Laura Chen said. Celestel added that a group of senior leaders has agreed to return cash incentives granted for 2023, totaling $9.1m, even though the company said they were not directly responsible for the accounting changes.

Wales hooker Mefin Davies is expected to remain at Gloucester despite fresh speculation linking him with a return to the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. Sources close to the situation say the Welsh region has sounded out the 32-year-old following his impressive display in Saturday’s Six Nations victory over England, but Davies is understood to be settled at Kingsholm and keen to extend his stay in the Premiership. The former Celtic Warriors player is currently tied to Gloucester on a short-term agreement, yet club officials are believed to be preparing discussions over a longer contract after a run of consistent performances. Davies’ move to England came after the collapse of the Warriors left several players without a regional deal, prompting him to take a part-time arrangement with Neath to maintain fitness and match sharpness. He later featured for the Ospreys with the backing of the Wales coaching staff, though he previously voiced frustration at the lack of support during the uncertain summer. Davies also considered an offer abroad before opting to keep his international prospects alive in England.

Prime Minister James Harrington is expected to set 12 May as the date for the next general election when Parliament reconvenes after the spring recess, according to the network’s chief political correspondent. The correspondent said Mr Harrington is likely to travel to Buckingham Palace in early April to request a dissolution, clearing the way for a campaign beginning almost immediately. The prime minister has so far avoided confirming a timetable, despite growing pressure from opposition leaders and intensified activity by all major parties in recent days.

Downing Street declined to comment on the reported schedule, insisting that the decision rests solely with the prime minister. A No 10 spokesperson said only that an announcement would be made “in due course” and would not be drawn on specific dates.

If the dissolution is sought at the start of April, Westminster would face a compressed final week of business as ministers attempt to complete priority legislation before MPs are sent back to their constituencies. Government whips are understood to be focusing on securing passage of the Finance Bill implementing the Budget measures, which must be enacted before the end of the session. Officials are also seeking to finalise the Public Safety and Serious Crime Bill and a long-delayed Digital Identity proposal, both of which have faced lengthy scrutiny in the Lords.

Speaking on the morning programme, the correspondent said there was “a broad expectation across the Commons” that the election would be called as soon as MPs return. While the administration is not required to go to the country until next year under the five-year limit, recent governments have often opted to seek a fresh mandate after about four years in office.

A prominent retirement research group has warned that Britain’s pension arrangements are failing to deliver clear and adequate support, arguing that the current framework is hard for savers to understand and leaves gaps for many people. The institute said a simplified state benefit, linked to years of lawful residence rather than National Insurance records, could make entitlements more transparent and narrow disparities between those with stable careers and those with time out of work. It suggested that people with interrupted employment—such as carers and workers on irregular contracts—are more likely to miss out under contribution-based rules. The comments follow the release of an interim review by an independent pensions panel examining long-term retirement funding. That review estimates millions of employees are building up insufficient resources for later life, raising the risk of lower living standards in old age. It said closing the shortfall would likely require a mix of greater individual saving, higher public funding and/or people working longer on average.

Australian carrier Qantas said it delivered its strongest first-half result on record after a renewed focus on trimming expenses and improving aircraft utilisation, but cautioned that momentum is likely to ease in the months ahead. The airline reported net profit of A$462m for the six months to 31 December, up 26% from the same period a year earlier and slightly ahead of market expectations of about A$440m. Despite the upbeat headline figure, shares slipped more than 2% in early trading as management signalled softer conditions in the second half.

Executives said revenue would be weighed down by weaker leisure demand following the Indian Ocean tsunami, which disrupted travel plans across parts of Asia and diverted bookings away from affected resort destinations. Chief executive Geoff Dixon said the company had seen an immediate shift in passenger behaviour, with a notable pullback in inbound travel from Japan and a rise in short-notice cancellations. Qantas estimated the impact would shave at least A$30m from sales, though it added that demand for some domestic routes had held up.

The airline also pointed to rising jet fuel prices as a growing headwind. Chief financial officer Peter Gregg said Qantas had benefited from a stronger fuel-hedging position earlier in the year, but that protection would be less pronounced in the second half, increasing exposure to market prices.

Competitive pressures are also intensifying. Qantas continues to face aggressive discounting from low-cost rival Virgin Blue, while government discussions about granting Singapore Airlines additional rights on trans-Pacific services could put pressure on one of Qantas’s most profitable corridors. Still, the company maintained guidance for higher full-year earnings, with analysts projecting profit of roughly A$720m. Qantas said it had already banked A$245m in cost reductions and remained on track to exceed its A$500m annual savings goal, even as it reviews longer-term staffing and outsourcing options.

Sir Richard Ellison, the Conservative MP whose low-key leadership bid against Prime Minister Harold Bennett in 1992 helped expose divisions inside the party, has died at the age of 86. His family said he passed away on Tuesday at his home in Surrey after a prolonged illness. Though Ellison never expected to win, his challenge was widely viewed as a “marker” that emboldened senior figures to consider a full contest later that year, a sequence that ultimately contributed to Bennett’s resignation and the rise of William Harcourt after a subsequent ballot. Ellison later faced a backlash at constituency level and was not reselected ahead of the 1997 general election, bringing to an end a parliamentary career spanning more than two decades. Born in October 1938, he was educated at Winchester College and Trinity College, Cambridge. After national service with the Grenadier Guards, he worked in the diplomatic service, focusing on European policy, before entering politics. He first won the marginal seat of Westford in 1974 by fewer than 50 votes, lost it at the next election, and returned to the Commons in 1979. Colleagues said his independence and willingness to dissent limited his prospects of ministerial office.

Former Aston Villa manager Martin O’Neill has ruled himself out of the running to take over at Birmingham City, despite being identified as a leading candidate by the club’s board. The Northern Irishman, who previously worked across the city at Villa Park, said the role was appealing in most respects but would be difficult to accept given his recent history in the area. O’Neill was approached earlier this week by Birmingham’s chief executive following the departure of head coach Mark Hughes, who left St Andrew’s to join fellow Championship side West Bromwich Albion.  

Speaking to local radio, O’Neill noted that the job offered strong foundations, including a well-supported stadium, an established training base and a squad he believes has the potential to challenge higher up the table. However, he added that taking charge of a direct rival so soon after his last spell in the region could create unnecessary complications.  

Birmingham have been placed under interim leadership since Hughes’ exit, with first-team matters currently handled by assistant coach Gary Rowett and academy director Steve Spooner. The caretaker pairing oversaw a four-match unbeaten run before Saturday’s 2-1 loss to promotion contenders Leeds United, leaving the club 13th in the standings. O’Neill has been out of management since stepping down last spring, having previously held posts at Sunderland, Celtic and Leicester City.

UK borrowing costs are expected to stay unchanged at 4.75% after the Bank of England’s latest policy meeting, as officials weigh easing momentum against persistent inflation risks. The Monetary Policy Committee has raised rates five times over the past 12 months, but has paused since September as recent data suggest the economy is losing some pace. Output growth moderated in the last quarter, with factory activity weakening and surveys pointing to a dip in household sentiment. Economists also say the housing market, which had been a key driver of domestic demand, is showing clearer signs of cooling. Nationwide reported that average house prices slipped 0.4% in October, the sharpest monthly decline since early 2001, adding to evidence of softer conditions for buyers and sellers. Bank governor Mervyn King last month described the economy as moving through a “softer patch” after a strong start to 2004, a view echoed by market analysts who see little urgency for tighter policy this month. Richard Jeffrey, chief economist at Bridgewell Securities, said the recent run of weaker indicators makes another immediate rise unlikely, though he cautioned that the current lull may not last. “It would be a mistake to assume the peak is in,” he said, adding that further increases remain possible if demand firms.

The dark comedy-drama The Last Detour emerged as the standout at this year’s Independent Spirit Awards, taking home every prize it was in contention for, including best feature. Director Lena Hart accepted trophies for both directing and original screenplay, sharing the writing honor with collaborator Miles Kwon. The film’s cast was also recognized, with lead actor Daniel Reyes winning best male performance, co-star Maren Elliott earning best supporting performance, and character actor Saul Benitez taking an ensemble-related acting prize. With multiple Academy Award nominations already secured, The Last Detour is widely viewed as a strong contender ahead of Sunday’s Oscars, which the Spirit Awards traditionally precede.

Elsewhere in the ceremony, newcomer Isla Torres won best female performance for her portrayal of a migrant worker in the border-set drama Dust Country, a film that also earned its writer-director, Priya Nair, the award for best first screenplay. Comedian-turned-filmmaker Jordan Pike collected best first feature for the semi-autobiographical indie Upstate, which he also wrote and starred in. The foreign-language prize went to the Romanian period piece The Orchard’s Silence, while the documentary award was claimed by Freight Train Nation, an observational look at the modern supply chain. Rising performer Mateo Rivas received the debut performance honor for his role in the coming-of-age road film Northbound.

The winners were selected by the membership of Film Independent, a voting body made up of industry professionals across acting, directing, writing and production. Last year’s top Spirit Awards winner later translated that momentum into an Oscar victory in the screenplay category.

Arsenal midfielder Gilberto Silva has offered an account of the heated moments that unfolded after the Gunners’ recent defeat to Manchester United, confirming that emotions ran high in the immediate aftermath of the final whistle. Speaking to reporters, the Brazilian said the scene in the tunnel area was tense, with players and staff needing to be separated as tempers threatened to boil over. “There was a lot of shouting and pointing, and people trying to get in each other’s faces,” he said, while adding that he could not confirm suggestions that objects were thrown toward United manager Sir Alex Ferguson. “I didn’t see any food or drink being aimed at anyone,” Silva noted.

Silva sought to put the confrontation into context, arguing that post-match flare-ups are not uncommon in high-stakes fixtures. He said he had experienced more volatile occasions during derby matches in Brazil, though he acknowledged the rivalry between the clubs adds an extra edge.

However, Silva was critical of the intensity of several United challenges during the match, pointing in particular to tackles on winger José Antonio Reyes. He claimed Arsenal’s approach had been more disciplined and suggested at least one challenge warranted stronger punishment from the referee.

The Football Association said it is gathering reports on the tunnel incident and will review match officials’ submissions. Separate disciplinary action is also being considered following allegations of serious foul play, while Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger has been asked to clarify remarks made after the contest.

Premier League officials are working to arrange a date for a hearing into claims that Chelsea improperly contacted Arsenal defender Ashley Cole. The league has indicated that both clubs will be invited to present their accounts before an independent commission, though no firm timetable has been set for when the session will take place. A league representative said discussions are continuing to identify a suitable window, noting that the process is not tied to a strict response period.

The matter centres on reports that Cole met Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho and chief executive Peter Kenyon at a London hotel earlier this month. If such talks took place without Arsenal’s permission, they could constitute a breach of the league’s regulations governing approaches to contracted players. Chelsea have not issued a detailed public statement addressing the alleged meeting, while Arsenal have formally requested that the league examine what they describe as an unauthorised attempt to lure the England international away.

Both sides have signalled they will co-operate with the inquiry, which is expected to be handled in a single sitting rather than as a prolonged investigation. Any findings could lead to sanctions if wrongdoing is established, although the league has not indicated what outcomes it is considering.

Cole’s club future remains under scrutiny as he continues discussions with Arsenal over a new contract. His current agreement is set to run until 2007, and negotiations are understood to be ongoing. Within the Arsenal dressing room, teammates have publicly encouraged him to remain, with Robert Pires highlighting the left-back’s long association with the club and his suitability to the team’s attacking style. Pires also acknowledged that, ultimately, the decision rests with the player.

Sir Paul McCartney took the stage in Berlin on Saturday night for a one-off benefit concert aimed at supporting communities hit by last month’s earthquake in southern Turkey and northern Syria. The former Beatle played to a crowd of about 2,500 at the Staatsoper Unter den Linden, in an event organisers said was designed both to raise funds and to showcase a wider range of contemporary performances at the historic opera house. Proceeds will be directed to the humanitarian group Kinderhilfe Europa, which plans to help reopen a damaged school and provide temporary learning spaces for displaced children.

McCartney delivered a set drawing on decades of material, mixing well-known chart favourites with quieter ballads, accompanied on piano and acoustic guitar, and backed by a small ensemble. The performance ran for nearly three hours and proceeded without an intermission, with the audience repeatedly rising to applaud between songs.

Among those attending were former German president Joachim Gauck and several members of Berlin’s cultural community, as well as visiting diplomats. Speaking briefly from the stage, McCartney reflected on his long career and said the evening was intended to “turn attention into practical help” for families struggling to rebuild.

Separately, organisers said a charity single is being prepared featuring McCartney and singer Adele on a new recording of a classic pop standard, with an announcement on its release expected in the coming weeks.

Organisers of the US Vibe Awards said the ceremony will return next year, despite a knife attack that disrupted this month’s event in Santa Monica. Vibe magazine president Kenard Gibbs called the incident “disturbing” and said cancelling the awards would undermine the publication’s long-standing efforts to spotlight hip-hop artists and industry achievements. The violence broke out moments before producer and rapper Dr Dre was set to accept a lifetime honour, when a man from the audience moved toward the stage area and struck the performer, witnesses said. Police allege that rapper Young Buck then stabbed the man during the chaos that followed, as security tried to separate those involved. Young Buck, whose legal name is David Darnell Brown, has been arrested and charged with attempted murder and assault with a deadly weapon, and is scheduled to appear in court on 20 December. Brown is affiliated with 50 Cent’s G-Unit collective, which has ties to Dr Dre’s record label. The injured man, identified as Jimmy James Johnson, was taken to a Los Angeles hospital with a punctured lung and was listed in stable condition. Investigators said the confrontation escalated quickly amid a crowd of about 1,000 attendees, prompting additional security and police to intervene.

Shares in Mizuho Financial Group and Nomura Holdings advanced on Thursday after market talk suggested the two Japanese financial heavyweights are exploring a broad tie-up that could include a merger. The business daily Asahi Shimbun reported that senior executives from both groups have recently exchanged views on deeper cooperation and have sounded out regulators about potential obstacles, citing people familiar with the matter. Both companies issued statements saying no formal decision had been made, while acknowledging ongoing discussions on joint initiatives in areas such as asset management and retail investment products.

Mizuho shares rose 2.1% to 2,435 yen in Tokyo trading, while Nomura gained 4.6% to 922 yen. A combination of the country’s second-largest banking group by assets and its biggest brokerage would create one of Japan’s largest financial conglomerates, with consolidated assets that analysts estimate would exceed $1 trillion, depending on the structure.

Mizuho President Masahiro Kihara said the industry faces “intensifying competition and structural change,” adding that partnerships could help improve profitability and broaden customer offerings. Nomura said it continues to evaluate collaborations that “enhance client value,” but stressed it is not currently in active talks to integrate the businesses.

Analysts noted that pressure from low interest rates and rising compliance costs is pushing firms toward scale, and that deregulation has made it easier to sell banking and investment services side by side.

Singer and songwriter Jamie Carver is expected to spend the weekend in custody after failing to lodge £150,000 in surety required to secure his release on bail by the court’s deadline. Carver, 26, was granted conditional bail at Highbury Corner Magistrates’ Court on charges of robbery and blackmail, but his solicitor told the court the funds could not be assembled in time. The performer was arrested following an alleged incident at a London hotel on Wednesday night. A second defendant, musician Daniel Reeves, 24, from north London, appeared alongside him and faces the same allegations.

Magistrates imposed strict restrictions on Carver, including a nightly curfew from 10pm to 7am, with an exemption permitting attendance at a drug treatment programme. The court ordered that he must not leave his address unless accompanied by a private security provider, must hand over his passport, and must report to a local police station each day. Reeves was also placed under a curfew and required to surrender travel documents.

Police were called to the hotel in Islington after reports of an assault. A man in his 30s was taken to University College Hospital with facial injuries and was later discharged, officers said. Speaking outside court, a lawyer for both defendants said they “categorically deny” the accusations and will contest the case. Carver, who rose to prominence with the indie group The Southbound Lines before continuing with his own project, is due back in court next week.

Four-time Olympic gold medallist Michael Johnson has questioned whether Britain’s leading sprinters are aiming high enough, saying domestic rivalries have too often taken precedence over global success. Speaking to BBC Radio 5 Live, the former 200m and 400m world record holder argued that the primary goal for many athletes appears to be topping the national rankings, rather than consistently challenging the world’s best at major championships. He said sprinting is ultimately judged on international performance and suggested British runners need to bring a stronger sense of purpose when competing abroad.

Johnson’s comments prompted a swift response from ex-world champion Linford Christie, who warned against overlooking the realities of Britain’s development system. Christie said it can be simple to offer judgments from the outside and stressed that pathways, competition structures and support in the UK differ from those in the United States.

The American has previously clashed with British sprinter Darren Campbell, after questioning Campbell’s explanation that a hamstring injury contributed to his failure to make the Olympic finals in both the 100m and 200m earlier this year. Johnson has maintained that British sprinting can appear more animated by internal disputes than by the pursuit of medals on the biggest stages.

Addressing an elite coaching conference in Birmingham, he also cast doubt on the idea that increased funding alone will lead to better outcomes. While acknowledging the growing financial backing for athletics in Britain, Johnson said success depends on culture, competition and mindset as much as resources. He contrasted the situation with some American athletes who train with limited support, arguing that difficult circumstances can sharpen focus and increase appreciation when opportunities arise.

January discounting has done little to lift Britain’s High Street after a weak festive period, according to a new industry survey. Retailers reported an early surge in shoppers chasing marked-down goods, but footfall and spending eased back as the month progressed, the British Retail Consortium said in figures compiled with consultancy partner KPMG. Like-for-like sales in January were up 0.6% on the same month a year earlier, a modest improvement for a period that is typically one of the strongest outside Christmas.

BRC chief executive Helen Dickinson said households are still holding back on major purchases such as sofas and home electronics, with higher borrowing costs continuing to squeeze budgets. The group pointed to softer confidence amid uncertainty in the housing market and slower wage growth as factors weighing on discretionary spending.

Some categories performed better than others. Clothing and footwear fared more strongly than in December, while a number of department stores reported solid demand for beauty products and small gifts. By contrast, retailers selling furniture and larger household goods described trading as “subdued” despite extended sales and additional promotions.

Over the three months to January, like-for-like sales were flat, unchanged from the previous three-month period, the survey found. The BRC said retailers may face further pressure in the months ahead as consumers prioritise essentials and continue to seek value.

Telecoms equipment maker Nokia Networks reported higher fourth-quarter earnings as major operators including Orange and Telefónica stepped up investment in 5G and fibre upgrades. Operating profit for the three months to 31 December reached €1.12bn, up from €820m a year earlier, the company said on Thursday. The shares fell in early trading after Nokia posted an operating margin of 41.9%, below the 43.0% level expected by analysts and slightly down from 42.6% in the previous quarter. Revenue rose 7% to €7.6bn, supported by stronger demand for radio access gear and service contracts tied to network modernisation projects.

Management said industry fundamentals remained favourable, citing continued growth in mobile data usage and the expansion of private wireless networks for enterprise customers. Chief executive Pekka Lundmark noted that more than one-third of global subscribers are now on 5G-capable plans, calling it a “multi-year replacement cycle” for operators. However, he cautioned that the order pattern seen late last year could ease as carriers digest earlier spending and work through inventory. Nokia said it expects seasonally softer sales in the first quarter and reiterated its full-year outlook, projecting steady profitability and disciplined cost control. For the full year, net profit climbed to €2.9bn from €2.1bn, while sales increased to €30.4bn from €28.7bn.

Rapper Eminem has prevented Elvis Presley from securing a fourth chart-topper this year after “Like Toy Soldiers” debuted at number one on the singles chart. The track edged out Presley’s newly reissued “Are You Lonesome Tonight,” the latest release in a planned run of 18 remastered singles tied to the 70th anniversary of the singer’s birth. Entering the countdown at number three was “Almost Here,” a collaboration between former Westlife member Brian McFadden and Australian singer Delta Goodrem. “Like Toy Soldiers,” taken from Eminem’s album “Encore,” draws on a hook from Martika’s 1980s hit “Toy Soldiers” and continues the rapper’s recent run of success following “Just Lose It,” while addressing ongoing rivalries within hip-hop. Last week’s chart leader, Presley’s “It’s Now or Never,” dropped sharply, falling 13 places to number 14, though five Presley reissues remained inside the Top 40. Elsewhere, charity single “Grief Never Grows Old,” recorded by the One World Project to raise funds for tsunami relief, slipped to number eight. In the album rankings, Athlete moved into first place with “Tourist,” pushing the Chemical Brothers down to number six with “Push the Button.”

A record label linked to late R&B singer Aaliyah has been turned back in its effort to bring a lawsuit against the video-production contractor that arranged the aircraft used in the trip that ended in her fatal 2001 crash. An appellate court in New York ruled that the right to pursue a wrongful-death claim rests with the artist’s next of kin, not with her company, leaving the label without standing to sue. Aaliyah, 22, died along with eight others when a small plane went down shortly after takeoff in the Bahamas following the completion of a video shoot. Her relatives previously resolved their claims in a confidential agreement reached in 2003. Attorneys for the label said they were reviewing the ruling and had not decided whether to seek further review. Investigators examining the crash concluded the aircraft was carrying more weight than permitted and found evidence that the pilot had consumed drugs and alcohol. Aaliyah, who had been expanding a career that spanned music and acting, was later honored with posthumous accolades, and several of her releases achieved major chart success.

Two of the biggest US carriers, Delta Air Lines and United Airlines, said surging jet fuel costs weighed heavily on their latest quarterly performance, underscoring how volatile energy markets continue to shape the industry’s outlook. Delta posted a net loss of $412m for the final quarter of 2025, compared with a $168m loss in the same period a year earlier, while United reported quarterly profit slipping 18% to $602m from $736m. Both airlines said fuel expenses rose sharply year on year and warned that elevated prices could keep margins under pressure into early 2026.

Delta, which has been working to rebuild profitability after a series of operational disruptions, said it expects results in the first quarter to remain weak as fuel bills and slower corporate travel demand collide with seasonal softness. United, the largest US carrier by international capacity, said it still anticipates remaining profitable but cautioned that its ability to offset higher costs will depend on ticket yields and capacity discipline across the market.

Investors reacted cautiously. Delta shares edged up 0.4% in morning trading after the company’s loss came in slightly narrower than some forecasts, while United stock fell 1.2% as analysts focused on softer unit revenue trends. Delta chief executive Ed Bastian said the quarter reflected “an operating environment defined by unusually high input costs and intense competition,” adding that the carrier would continue to prioritize efficiency initiatives.

For the full year, Delta reported a net loss of $980m, an improvement from the prior year’s $1.6bn deficit, citing lower non-fuel costs and stronger premium demand. The airline also said it would defer delivery of 38 narrow-body aircraft to preserve cash and better match capacity to demand. Analysts said fare pressure remains a risk as airlines add seats in key domestic routes, keeping prices competitive even as costs rise.

Music executive Marion “Suge” Knight was taken into custody over the weekend on suspicion of violating the conditions of his parole after authorities said they discovered marijuana during a traffic stop in Southern California. Knight was arrested Saturday in the Barstow area after officers pulled over a vehicle for an alleged moving violation, law enforcement officials said. He is expected to be held pending a hearing that will determine whether he will remain jailed or be returned to state prison while the alleged breach is reviewed.

Police reported that the stop occurred after the driver made an illegal turn. During a subsequent search, officers said they found suspected marijuana inside the car. Knight was also cited for an alleged insurance-related infraction, according to the report.

A woman riding in the vehicle, described by police as 18 years old, was also detained on suspicion of providing inaccurate identifying information and possessing a counterfeit identification card. Authorities said she was later released.

Knight, the founder of Death Row Records, has faced repeated legal problems over the years and has previously served jail time stemming from parole issues. In 2004, he completed a 10-month sentence linked to an incident in which prosecutors said he assaulted a man while still under supervision for an earlier conviction.

His name has long been associated with the tumultuous era of 1990s West Coast hip-hop. Knight was involved in a Las Vegas altercation in 1996 shortly before rapper Tupac Shakur was fatally shot in a drive-by attack; Knight was driving the vehicle Shakur rode in and was wounded. Death Row Records, which helped launch major careers including Shakur’s and Dr. Dre’s, has also drawn criticism for alleged ties to gang culture and for exacerbating rap’s regional rivalries.

Shares in Midlands-based miner BritCoal slid on Thursday after the company reported a sharply wider annual loss, highlighting continued disruption at several of its underground operations. The firm said it posted a deficit of £48.9m for 2024, compared with a £3.4m loss a year earlier, citing difficult seam conditions, unplanned equipment downtime and stoppages linked to pay talks. In morning trading, the stock fell 9% to 121p.

Chief executive Martin Keane, appointed in September, said the group was working to stabilise output and improve reliability across its deepest pits. BritCoal outlined a programme of operational changes, including revised shift incentives, a tighter preventative maintenance schedule and new extraction techniques designed to keep production moving when water ingress and roof instability occur.

Management described 2025 as a “reset period” and said it was targeting a return to positive earnings in 2026, provided productivity initiatives take hold and disruption eases. The company added that stronger coal market prices had not materially lifted results because much of its output was committed under earlier contracts at lower rates.

BritCoal said its average production cost rose to £1.33 per gigajoule, while realised prices averaged £1.19 per gigajoule, squeezing margins. The group operates a network of 13 surface and deep mines across Yorkshire, Nottinghamshire, Derbyshire, Northumberland and the West Midlands.

South Korea’s Hyundai Motor said it will construct a second manufacturing facility in India as it seeks to capitalize on rising vehicle demand and expand its regional footprint. The automaker did not disclose the size of the investment, but said the new site will have an annual capacity of about 150,000 vehicles. Once operational, the additional plant would lift Hyundai’s total output capability in India—where it ranks as the country’s second-largest car producer—to roughly 400,000 units a year, the company said. Hyundai also outlined ambitious sales targets, projecting mid-teens growth in domestic deliveries in the near term and indicating that volumes could climb to around 400,000 vehicles by the end of the decade if market conditions remain favorable. The new factory is expected to be located near the company’s existing complex outside Chennai in the southern state of Tamil Nadu, a hub for auto and components manufacturing. Hyundai forecast that India’s overall passenger-vehicle market will continue to expand at a double-digit pace, approaching one million sales this year and moving toward 1.6 million by 2010. Industry analysts attribute the increase to expanding disposable incomes, limited public transportation options in many cities, and still-low private car ownership, which remains well below levels seen in developed economies. The company said it intends to use India not only to serve local buyers but also as an export platform for markets including Europe, Latin America and the Middle East, as part of its broader effort to climb into the top tier of global automakers.

A cannabis-derived prescription medicine developed by British biotech company GW Pharmaceuticals is moving closer to regulatory clearance in Canada, potentially opening a new treatment option for people with multiple sclerosis (MS). The product, known as Sativex, is designed to ease neurological symptoms associated with MS, including spasticity and pain. The development comes after a turbulent period for the firm, whose share price fell sharply in recent weeks when UK health authorities signaled they were not yet satisfied with the evidence supporting the drug’s clinical benefits. Canadian regulators have now indicated the application has progressed to the next stage of review, raising expectations that a decision could be reached within months.

MS affects an estimated 50,000 Canadians and tens of thousands of people in the UK. Patient groups say some sufferers already use smoked cannabis to manage symptoms, though doing so remains legally and medically problematic. If authorized, Sativex would offer a standardized dose delivered as an oral spray, potentially providing a regulated alternative to self-medication.

Industry analysts described the Canadian process as a significant milestone, noting that formal approval would mark one of the first instances worldwide of a pharmaceutical product based directly on cannabis extracts receiving national authorization. GW Pharmaceuticals said it is preparing for a possible launch early next year, assuming no major delays during final evaluation.

The company holds a UK government licence to cultivate cannabis for research and manufacturing. Sativex contains measured amounts of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and cannabidiol (CBD), compounds that researchers believe work together to reduce certain MS-related symptoms; the formulation is also being studied for other conditions, including inflammatory pain. Production relies on tightly controlled cultivation in the UK, with security measures typical of high-value pharmaceutical crops.

News of the Canadian review update lifted investor sentiment, with GW Pharmaceuticals’ shares edging higher in London trading as markets weighed the prospects for the company’s first major commercial approval.

Bath prop Matt Stevens has been drafted into England’s enlarged 30-man group for next weekend’s Six Nations trip to Dublin as head coach Steve Borthwick scrambles to cover a mounting injury list in the front row. With tighthead options stretched by Dan Cole’s calf problem and Will Stuart managing a shoulder complaint, Stevens has been placed on standby and could be in line for a first Test appearance if either player fails to prove fitness during the week.

Stevens, 29, had previously explored the possibility of representing Scotland through family links, but a review of his international status by World Rugby confirmed he is tied to England after featuring for an England age-grade side earlier in his career. The late call-up is a reward for strong Premiership form and for his performance in the recent England A fixture, where he impressed in the set-piece and played a role in two tries during a narrow win over a French selection.

England’s coaches are also weighing up alternative combinations in the scrum. Sale’s uncapped Asher Opoku-Fordjour remains an option, though he has spent much of this season on the loosehead side, and the staff are wary of changing the balance of the front row against an Irish pack renowned for pressure at the breakdown and in the tight exchanges.

There are further concerns in midfield after centre Manu Tuilagi was withdrawn late from club duty at the weekend with a hamstring issue. He is scheduled for a scan, while Ireland are monitoring the condition of utility back Jimmy O’Brien, who left Leinster’s match with an ankle knock. Despite those uncertainties, England are expected to keep faith with their established backline, with Harlequins’ Oscar Beard identified as the most likely replacement should a change be required.

The squad is due to assemble at England’s training base on Monday, with final selection decisions anticipated after midweek medical assessments.

Japanese telecoms and internet group SoftBank reported a deeper quarterly loss as it ramped up promotion of a newly introduced low-priced mobile plan aimed at budget-conscious customers. The company said the service, unveiled in December, has drawn close to 900,000 applications, but the rollout has required substantial marketing outlays. For the three months ending in December, SoftBank posted an operating loss of 7.5bn yen ($71.5m; £38.4m), compared with a smaller deficit a year earlier. Executives indicated the core business would have been profitable without the launch-related spending and said they expect results to turn positive during 2006, though they declined to provide a specific earnings forecast. SoftBank rose to prominence during Japan’s technology boom in the 1990s before being hit by the subsequent downturn, and has since rebuilt its profile through acquisitions. Its purchase of Japan Telecom helped strengthen its broadband unit, which ended December with more than 5.1 million subscribers, keeping it among the market leaders.

Model and entrepreneur Caprice and Holby City actor Jeremy Edwards have both exited the Celebrity Big Brother house following an unexpected double eviction on Friday night. Caprice was the latest contestant to leave in the programme’s planned fourth eviction, receiving just 5% of the public vote, and later told viewers she felt relieved to be out of the competition. Edwards was then removed in a further twist, departing in a surprise vote with 12% backing him to stay. With the final approaching, 19-year-old Blazin’ Squad singer Kenzie is now the bookmakers’ leading pick to claim the £50,000 prize for charity. Before the show, Caprice had been widely tipped to go early, with Ladbrokes listing her as a strong favourite for eviction and describing her as the standout candidate to be voted out so far this series. After Friday’s result, betting firms cut the odds on Kenzie, though they cautioned that a late shift in public support could still benefit former Happy Mondays performer Bez. Actress Brigitte Nielsen remains in the house alongside the other finalists. Earlier in the week, DJ Lisa I’Anson became the third celebrity to be voted out after a surprise eviction staged during a hide-and-seek task, saying she was pleased to leave and predicting Kenzie would win. The series champion will be confirmed on Sunday night.

Japan’s major brewers are increasingly looking beyond traditional lager as high excise duties and cautious consumer spending reshape the market for alcoholic drinks. Companies say demand is accelerating for low-tax, beer-tasting beverages made with alternative ingredients that allow producers to price products below standard beer while keeping familiar flavour profiles. Asahi Breweries has forecast a sharp expansion this year in the category often described as “new-genre” or “beer-style” drinks, and expects earnings to strengthen as it rolls out a new product formulated with soybean-derived components instead of malt. Industry analysts note that branding is central to the strategy, with names and packaging designed to resemble draft beer even when the contents fall outside legal beer definitions. Rival producers have already established footholds: Sapporo has built sales around a malt-free option, while Suntory has pushed blended drinks that combine low-malt beverages with distilled spirits such as shochu. The shift has been underway for years, as households sought cheaper substitutes during Japan’s prolonged economic slump, and brewers capitalised on the lower tax brackets applied to reduced-malt and non-malt formulations. Kirin is also preparing a new entry in the fast-growing segment, intensifying competition in a market where price and taxation are increasingly decisive.

The move to factor digital music downloads into the official UK singles chart has been postponed by four weeks, after industry concerns that smaller labels could be disadvantaged under the current online retail landscape. The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) had been preparing to introduce download sales into the chart from 20 March, but the start date has now been shifted to 17 April while efforts are made to improve the visibility and availability of independent releases on major download services. BPI officials said they want to ensure that the chart reflects a broader range of music, noting that the catalogue carried by leading online outlets does not always match what is stocked in traditional retail. 

BPI chairman Peter Jamieson described the planned change as a major milestone for the charts, but said it should not proceed until there is greater confidence that independent repertoire is properly represented across digital platforms. He added that the delay would allow discussions with download retailers and chart administrators to address gaps in listings and reporting.

The Official UK Charts Company (OCC), which compiles the rankings as a joint venture between the BPI and the British Association of Record Dealers, agreed to the revised timetable at a board meeting on Wednesday. Under the new schedule, downloads will count towards the singles chart for the first time in the edition published on 17 April, covering sales from the week beginning 10 April. Similar chart integration has already taken place in the United States with Billboard’s main singles ranking.

Motley Crue guitarist Mick Mars is facing a $10 million lawsuit filed by a former partner who alleges he reneged on assurances that he would continue supporting her financially after their relationship ended. The plaintiff, Robin Mantooth, claims that throughout their time together Mars repeatedly promised to look after her if the couple separated, but she says he rejected the existence of any such arrangement when they broke up in December. In papers lodged in Los Angeles, Mantooth is seeking a division of assets, ongoing monthly payments and additional damages. She contends that the relationship began in 1990 and that she gave up her work as a documentary film-maker to live with the musician at his home in Malibu. Mantooth also alleges that since the split Mars, 53, has provided no financial assistance. The legal action comes as Motley Crue prepares for renewed activity following a five-year hiatus. Formed in the early 1980s, the band enjoyed a string of international successes, including charting singles in the UK. They are scheduled to begin a major tour later this year, with dates planned across the United States, Europe, Asia and Australia. Mars, whose birth name is Bob Allen Deal, recently underwent hip replacement surgery and has long lived with a degenerative rheumatic condition.

Rafael Nadal kept his momentum going at the Mexican Open in Acapulco, defeating Argentina’s Guillermo Canas to move into the semi-finals. The Spanish eighth seed, fresh from winning last week’s Brazil Open for his second ATP title, came through a tight opening set before pulling away to win 7-5 6-3. Nadal will next face Argentine wild card Mariano Puerta, who again upset the form book by edging Spain’s Felix Mantilla in a tense three-set contest, 6-4 3-6 7-6, after previously eliminating top seed Carlos Moya. In the other half of the draw, Argentina’s Agustin Calleri removed fifth-seeded Czech Jiri Novak 7-5 6-1, ending Novak’s bid to add to his past success at the event. Calleri, a former champion in Acapulco, set up a last-four meeting with Spain’s Albert Montanes. Montanes advanced to his first semi-final of the season by overturning a one-set deficit against sixth-seeded Italian Filippo Volandri, winning 4-6 6-3 6-4. Organizers said the semi-finals will be played later Friday under warm evening conditions on the coastal hard courts.

Nasdaq Stock Market Inc., the operator of the technology-heavy Nasdaq exchange, has filed paperwork with U.S. regulators outlining plans for a public share offering that would place its stock on the very market it runs. In a registration statement submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said the transaction is expected to raise about $100m, though the proceeds would go to existing shareholders rather than to Nasdaq itself. The shares being offered were acquired through earlier private placements completed in 2000 and 2001, the filing indicated. Market participants said the move could further advance Nasdaq toward a more conventional stock-market listing, even as the company has previously played down speculation about a broader flotation. Nasdaq’s shares have already been trading in a limited fashion since 2002 on the OTC Bulletin Board, a venue associated with lightly traded securities. The exchange’s identity remains closely tied to fast-growing technology and biotech businesses, and it became a defining barometer during the late-1990s internet surge before plunging when the bubble collapsed. Improved performance at large chipmakers and resilient online retailers has since helped restore investor appetite.

Matt Lucas and David Walliams have been ranked as the leading figures in British television comedy in a new annual survey compiled by the Radio Times. The Little Britain creators moved into first place ahead of Phoenix Nights writer and performer Peter Kay, who remains second, while The Office co-creator Ricky Gervais is placed third. The magazine said its panel assessed influence across the sector by weighing recent audience impact, industry recognition and commercial performance. Several performers entered the list for the first time, including Nighty Night actor Julia Davis, who appears in the top 10, and Black Books star Tamsin Greig, who features in the top 20. Lucas and Walliams’ climb follows a year of prominent awards attention for their sketch show, alongside strong viewing figures for the latest run on BBC Three, which delivered one of the channel’s biggest audiences since launch. Their ascent was also one of several notable shifts in the top 20: presenters Ant and Dec recorded a sharp rise into the top five, and Stephen Fry advanced further up the table after a busy year across entertainment and factual programming. BBC Three controller Stuart Murphy also gained ground, reflecting the growing profile of digital channels in commissioning comedy. By contrast, last year’s top-ranked name, chat show host Graham Norton, slipped down the order after a lighter on-screen schedule. The list also acknowledges production companies behind successful series, with outfits linked to multiple returning titles represented among the top 50.

Actor Michael Keaton has filed a lawsuit against Silver Gate Pictures, alleging he was injured during production of the action thriller Desert Line. In court papers lodged this week in Los Angeles County, Keaton says he suffered head and neck injuries after a pyrotechnic device malfunctioned during the filming of a battle scene on the 2003 movie, which the company helped finance and produce. The complaint seeks reimbursement for past and future medical treatment and alleges the incident caused ongoing physical discomfort and emotional distress.

A representative for Silver Gate Pictures declined to address the claims, citing the active legal case.

Desert Line, directed by veteran filmmaker Daniel Rourke, follows a U.S. special operations officer who defies an extraction order to escort civilians out of a conflict zone. The movie received mixed reviews at release and delivered only modest ticket sales, according to industry tracking services.

The lawsuit describes the incident as occurring during the use of small explosive charges intended to mimic impacts near an actor’s position. Keaton contends that a charge detonated closer than planned, striking him with debris and a pressure blast. The filing does not provide detailed medical records but states that he required evaluation and treatment from physicians and other healthcare providers.

Keaton is not asking for a specific dollar amount, instead requesting damages to be determined at trial. The complaint also names the production’s special-effects supervisor, alleging the defendants failed to properly inspect, place and coordinate the devices and did not ensure that qualified personnel handled the setup.

Greek sprinter Kostas Kenteris has rejected allegations that he engineered a traffic accident to sidestep a drug screening in the final days before the Olympic Games. Kenteris and fellow athlete Katerina Thanou are expected to be informed this week whether prosecutors will pursue criminal action linked to their failure to appear for an out-of-competition test. Investigators have been examining the circumstances of the incident, including claims that the pair may have staged the crash.

Speaking in a televised interview, Kenteris said the collision was real and described being overwhelmed when he learned officials believed he had missed the control. He said he set off in haste toward the Olympic Village in an effort to resolve the situation. Kenteris also maintained that he tried to undergo testing immediately after being taken to hospital, saying he asked medical staff at the Olympics-accredited facility to contact the International Olympic Committee so that samples could be collected there and then. According to Kenteris, no anti-doping representatives arrived during his stay.

The episode became a major story in Greece as Athens prepared to host the Games, and both Kenteris and Thanou later withdrew from competition. Kenteris has repeatedly asserted he did not attempt to evade testing and on Sunday accused Greek sporting officials and his former coach, Christos Tzekos, of failing to pass on information about the scheduled control.

The 31-year-old said he would welcome formal charges if they allow the case to be examined in court and his reputation to be restored. Kenteris, who won the Olympic 200 metres title in Sydney in 2000, also said he had been slated for a prominent ceremonial role at the opening of the Athens Games and had practiced for it before the controversy erupted.

Ticket buyers for this year’s Glastonbury Festival will receive personalised entry passes featuring a photograph and embedded electronic data, organisers have announced, in a move designed to curb ticket touting and counterfeit sales. The passes, which link the holder’s identity to a specific ticket, are expected to be issued ahead of the event in late June, with tickets due to be released in April.

Festival founder Michael Eavis said the new system is intended to ensure admissions are limited to those who purchased through authorised channels. He warned fans against buying from unofficial sellers, saying entry would be refused if the details on the pass did not match the person arriving at the gates.

Organisers said those who prefer not to carry the new pass may instead present recognised photo identification, such as a passport or driving licence, as a secondary option at check-in points. Staff will be equipped to verify details on site, with the aim of preventing ticket transfers and reducing forgeries.

More than 150,000 people are expected to attend the music and arts event on the Eavis family’s Somerset farm, and demand has continued to outstrip supply in recent years. The popularity of the festival has led to rapid sell-outs and a thriving resale market, prompting repeated efforts to tighten ticketing rules.

Emily Eavis, who helps run the festival, previously said organisers were considering stronger measures to protect genuine customers and discourage profiteering. Past attempts at personalisation, including printing purchasers’ names on tickets and requesting supporting documents at the gate, had mixed results, with some attendees arriving without the right paperwork and some resellers offering documents to match tickets.

No official line-up has been confirmed, although speculation about potential headline acts has begun circulating as the on-sale date approaches.

The government has moved to rebut media reports suggesting a shake-up at the top of Labour’s election operation, insisting there is no plan for Chancellor Gordon Brown to sideline campaign chief Alan Milburn. Work and pensions minister Alan Johnson said speculation about an internal power struggle was misplaced, arguing that senior figures were focused on presenting a united front as the party prepares for the next general election. His comments followed claims in the Sunday Business that Mr Brown had been asked to assume greater responsibility for media handling and overall messaging, with Mr Milburn shifting to a less prominent, coordinating position. Labour sources have long indicated the chancellor would be heavily involved in the campaign, but the latest reports come amid growing unease among some backbench MPs about the party’s performance against the Conservatives. Several MPs have privately complained that Labour has too often found itself reacting to Opposition initiatives rather than setting the agenda, a view echoed by commentators pointing to recent Conservative policy launches. The renewed talk of changes also follows a series of opinion polls indicating the gap between the parties has narrowed in recent weeks. Party strategists are said to be encouraged by internal tracking suggesting an uptick in support for Labour after last week’s Budget, increasing calls for Mr Brown to take a more visible role on the campaign trail. However, the Sunday Telegraph reported that Mr Milburn is resistant to any arrangement that would diminish his authority. Mr Johnson said both men would “work together” and dismissed suggestions of rivalry. Downing Street and Labour headquarters declined to address the reports directly.

Carlos Moya became the first player to retain the Chennai Open crown after outlasting Thailand’s Paradorn Srichaphan in a tense three-set final, winning 3-6 6-4 7-6 (7/5). Moments after lifting the trophy, the Spaniard said he would donate his £28,000 winner’s cheque to support victims of the Asian tsunami. Srichaphan, a former champion and four-time runner-up at the event, seized early control by taking the opening set, but Moya steadied his serve and broke late in the second to level the match. The deciding set swung repeatedly, with Moya trailing 5-2 before saving match points and dragging the contest into a tie-break he edged with aggressive baseline play. Tournament organisers said several players had already indicated they would contribute their earnings to relief operations, as the event proceeded in the wake of the 26 December catastrophe that has killed more than 150,000 people across the region. Srichaphan said he planned to make a separate donation for assistance in Thailand, where the death toll has exceeded 5,000. The ATP also confirmed a contribution to Unicef’s emergency fund in Tamil Nadu, with additional backing from tour sponsors.

Organisers of this year’s Berlin International Film Festival say the event, which begins Thursday with the historical drama *Man to Man*, will highlight a renewed momentum in European filmmaking. Of the 21 titles vying for the festival’s top prizes, a majority come from European directors, with French productions forming one of the largest national contingents. Festival director Dieter Kosslick told reporters that the selection reflects growing confidence across the continent’s industry and a run of strong critical and box-office performances. While noting that major U.S. releases continue to draw audiences, he said the current line-up shows Europe has expanded both its range and ambition. Kosslick also dismissed suggestions that political tensions, including debate over the Iraq war, have cooled local interest in American cinema, arguing that programming decisions were driven by quality rather than sentiment. Around 350 films are due to be screened during the 10-day festival, and a further 300 titles will be presented at the European Film Market running in parallel for buyers and distributors. A number of high-profile actors are expected to appear, including Will Smith, Kevin Spacey and Keanu Reeves, though Kosslick said scheduling conflicts created by the earlier date of the Academy Awards have limited some attendance. He added that organisers are considering moving the festival to January next year to reduce future clashes. The Berlinale runs through 20 February.

Foreign Secretary David Miliband is to travel to Poland later this month to attend events marking the 65th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz-Birkenau, officials have confirmed. The Duke of Gloucester will accompany the British delegation for National Holocaust Memorial Day ceremonies on 27 January, alongside representatives from survivor organisations and faith groups. Historians estimate that more than a million people, the vast majority of them Jews, were murdered at the camp complex during the Second World War.

The announcement follows criticism from opposition politicians after it emerged that a junior minister had initially been expected to represent the UK at the main commemoration. Conservative foreign affairs spokesman William Hague welcomed the change of plan but accused the government of acting only after pressure mounted. “It is right that Britain is properly represented at a moment of such gravity,” he said, adding that the decision should have been made earlier.

In London, the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh are due to lead a national service of remembrance at Westminster Hall, with senior figures from across public life invited to attend. Buckingham Palace said the Queen will also host a reception for survivors and their families at St James’s Palace.

The commemorations come as renewed attention has focused on the responsibilities of public figures after a member of the Royal Family drew condemnation for wearing an offensive costume at a private party. Jewish leaders have said the anniversary is an opportunity to confront the consequences of Nazi ideology and to reinforce education about the Holocaust, in which about six million Jews were killed.

Top seed Novak Djokovic fought off two match points before edging past Spain’s David Ferrer in a tense Dubai Open showdown on Wednesday. The world number one needed two hours and 20 minutes to secure a 4-6 6-3 7-6 win, recovering from 4-6 down in the deciding-set tiebreak to clinch it 8-6. Djokovic struggled to find rhythm in the opening set, spraying errors from the baseline as Ferrer capitalised with sharp returns and consistent depth. The Serb steadied in the second, raising his first-serve percentage and forcing longer rallies to pull level. In a nervy final set, both players held serve under pressure before the match turned on a handful of points in the breaker, where Djokovic saved two match points with aggressive forehands and then closed out on his own opportunity. He advances to the quarter-finals to meet seventh seed Andrey Rublev, who beat Germany’s Jan-Lennard Struff 7-5 6-4. Djokovic said he was not alarmed by another long match, noting he had recently been pushed to three sets in successive outings.

Band Aid 20’s charity re-recording has remained at the top of the singles chart for a second consecutive week, keeping it in a strong position in the run-up to the Christmas number one. The track, which brings together a range of contemporary artists including Chris Martin and Jamelia, once again fended off competition from Kylie Minogue, whose I Believe in You held steady in second place. Ice Cube’s You Can Do It slipped a spot to third, while Destiny’s Child dropped to fourth with Lose My Breath. Girls Aloud completed the top five with their Children in Need release I’ll Stand By You, continuing to attract attention through its fundraising ties as well as its chart performance.

Among the week’s movers, Robbie Williams secured the only new entry in the top 10 with Misunderstood, a song recorded for his Greatest Hits collection. Elsewhere on the albums chart, there were no fresh releases across the top 40, reflecting an industry strategy of front-loading major launches earlier in the season to maximise holiday sales.

U2’s How to Dismantle an Atom Bomb extended its reign at number one for a third week, with Williams’ Greatest Hits holding at two. Il Divo climbed to third, while Maroon 5’s Songs About Jane continued its gradual rise to seven despite having been available for nearly a year. Abba Gold also edged back into the top 40, years after its original release, underscoring the enduring seasonal appeal of familiar catalogue titles.

US rapper Travis Scott is facing a $30m (£24m) civil lawsuit from a former freelance stylist who alleges she was drugged and sexually assaulted by the artist and members of his entourage after a late-night television taping in 2022. The complaint, filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court on Monday, claims the woman attended an after-show gathering following a music performance recorded for a major broadcast network, where she says a drink offered to her was tampered with and she later lost consciousness. She alleges she awoke in a private room and was assaulted, and that security staff prevented her from leaving immediately. Scott has not been charged in connection with the allegations.

A spokesperson for the musician, whose real name is Jacques Webster, denied the claims, describing them as “categorically false” and saying the plaintiff was attempting to “pressure a settlement through sensational allegations.” The network named in the suit said it could not discuss pending litigation but maintained it had “strong policies and procedures” in place for guests and contractors. The lawsuit also names three unidentified associates, a production company involved in the taping, and the corporate parent of the broadcaster, alleging negligence and failure to provide a safe workplace.

The plaintiff’s attorney said the woman delayed filing suit while seeking a resolution outside court and because she feared professional retaliation. The filing requests damages for medical expenses, emotional distress, and lost income, and seeks a jury trial. Scott, a Grammy-nominated artist with multiple chart-topping releases, has previously denied misconduct allegations in unrelated matters.

Canadian video game studio BioWare is planning to stage public auditions this weekend to recruit members of the public whose likenesses could appear in upcoming titles. The role-playing game developer, known for franchises including Mass Effect and Dragon Age, said it is looking for volunteers aged 18 to 99 to serve as facial reference for in-game characters. The company said selected participants will be paid a performer’s fee in exchange for permission to use their image in future projects. Organisers are asking interested people to attend sessions at a shopping centre in west Edmonton, Alberta, on Friday and Saturday, and to bring government-issued photo identification to confirm age and identity.

A spokesperson involved in the casting process said the studio builds worlds populated by large ensembles, requiring a range of faces beyond those typically seen in traditional modelling calls. The company is seeking “everyday people” as well as individuals with distinctive features, to help create more varied crowds and supporting roles across different settings, from towns and markets to military outposts and remote villages.

Those selected will undergo a 3D capture process that involves taking extensive photographic references from multiple angles so artists can generate a detailed digital head model.
