The studio said the resulting scans are designed to reproduce facial structure and skin detail with high fidelity, allowing developers to create characters that look believable at close range.

BioWare also said participants should understand that once the scanning is complete, the studio retains creative control over how the likeness is applied. A face may be used in different contexts across projects, potentially appearing as a protagonist in one game, a minor non-player character in another, or a villain elsewhere. The company said it would not be able to offer editorial approval over storylines, costumes, or character roles.

Defending champions Manchester United and Premier League pace-setters Chelsea have been handed demanding trips in the FA Cup fifth round draw, with United set to visit Everton and Chelsea heading to Newcastle. Two lower-league survivors remain in contention after Brentford and Hartlepool were paired again in a replay, the winners earning an away match at Southampton. Burnley, meanwhile, were given a home fixture against local rivals Blackburn in an all-Lancashire clash. The meeting at Goodison Park is likely to attract added attention following Wayne Rooney’s high-profile switch from Everton to United, with the forward in line to face his former side for the first time since the move. Elsewhere, Nottingham Forest could be sent to West Bromwich Albion should the Baggies progress from their fourth-round replay with Tottenham. Arsenal were drawn at home and will meet either West Ham United or Sheffield United, depending on the outcome of their replay. Charlton Athletic were paired with Leicester City, while Bolton Wanderers will take on Derby County or Fulham once their tie is decided. The fifth-round matches are scheduled to be played over the weekend of 19 and 20 February.

A record number of schools across the UK are preparing to stage a nationwide mock general election in a government-supported programme designed to spark pupils’ interest in public life. Organisers said around 600 schools have already enrolled in the Y Vote Mock Elections 2005, coordinated by the Hansard Society, with more expected to join before voting begins. Participating pupils will take on roles commonly found in election campaigns, including standing as candidates, drafting speeches, planning messages and canvassing classmates for support.

Schools Minister Stephen Twigg said encouraging political understanding among young people was vital for the long-term strength of democratic participation. He said the project was intended to help pupils learn how elections work, why they matter, and how individual involvement can shape outcomes. By running campaigns and taking part in the count, he added, students would gain first-hand experience of the responsibilities and choices that come with voting.

The programme is being delivered in partnership with the Electoral Commission and the Department for Education and Skills. Michael Raftery, the Hansard Society’s project manager, said the aim was to recreate the atmosphere of a real contest while promoting citizenship education and informed debate in schools. He said mock ballots could help students understand competing priorities and the practical challenges parties face when trying to persuade voters.

Voting in schools is expected to take place in early May, close to the date widely anticipated for the next general election. Election packs sent to invited schools include ballot papers, guidance for running polling stations and materials to help pupils compare manifesto promises and key issues.

England prop Dan Cole has vowed to keep his focus on conditioning after a forearm fracture ended his hopes of featuring in this season’s Six Nations. The 33-year-old sustained the injury in Leicester Tigers’ 22-19 Premiership victory over Northampton Saints on Saturday, with scans later confirming a break to the ulna in his left arm. Cole is scheduled to have surgery early this week and is expected to be sidelined for six to eight weeks, putting his international availability in doubt.

Cole said he was determined to remain involved at the club while he recovers. “It’s obviously disappointing, but it doesn’t stop you doing the work you can do,” he said. “Once the operation is done, the plan is to get back in the gym quickly and keep the fitness side ticking over.”

He added that he had sought advice from team-mate James Cronin, who missed part of last season with a similar problem. “He told me the first few days are the toughest and then you can start moving forward again,” Cole said. “Hearing that helps, because you want to keep a routine and stay connected.”

Leicester head coach Michael Cheika described the timing as “cruel” after Cole had completed his first full match since December. “Dan has been building nicely and needed the minutes,” Cheika said. “He’s in excellent shape, and the frustrating part is that this comes just as he was finding rhythm. We’ll support him through the process, but it’s a significant blow.”

Top seed Alex de Minaur was sent tumbling out of the Brisbane International on Friday after a straight-sets loss to American hard-hitter Ben Shelton in the quarter-finals. De Minaur, touted as one of the favourites in the final tune-up events ahead of the Australian Open, was edged 7-6 (7-5) 6-4 as Shelton relied on a heavy serve and aggressive first-strike tennis to blunt the home player’s speed.

Shelton will meet Argentina’s Francisco Cerundolo in the semi-finals after the fifth seed defeated Austria’s Sebastian Ofner 6-3 3-6 6-2 in the day’s earlier match. In the other half of the draw, Belgium’s David Goffin rallied past third seed Karen Khachanov 4-6 7-6 (9-7) 6-4 and will face second seed Grigor Dimitrov, who advanced by beating fellow Bulgarian Adrian Andreev 6-2 4-6 6-1.

“I was serving well when it mattered and stayed calm in the tiebreak,” Shelton said. “Against a guy who gets so many balls back, you can’t let up.”

De Minaur downplayed the setback, saying his priority remains peaking in Melbourne. “This is part of the process,” he said. “The goal is to be ready for the Australian Open, and that’s where I want my best tennis.”

Baroness Betty Boothroyd has called for the House of Lords to appoint a dedicated presiding officer, arguing that members of the upper chamber should take greater responsibility for shaping its future. Speaking in a broadcast interview, the former Commons Speaker said the current constitutional arrangements left the Lords without clear leadership inside the chamber and risked undermining public confidence. She suggested that earlier changes to the Lords were introduced without sufficient agreement on the final destination, leaving peers and ministers to manage the consequences years later. “If reform is to mean anything, it needs a plan and it needs ownership,” she said.

The Labour government’s 1999 legislation removed the automatic right of most hereditary peers to sit and vote, leaving a small number in place on an interim basis while wider reform was considered. The move was presented as an initial step in a broader process, but successive administrations have struggled to settle on a lasting model for membership and powers.

Ministers indicated that further proposals could feature in the party’s next election platform, though they declined to set out details. Lord Falconer, the lord chancellor, said the balance of authority between the Commons and the Lords remained central to any overhaul, including how the two Houses resolve disagreements and scrutinise legislation. He said any commitments would be made in due course.

Under current arrangements, the lord chancellor performs the Lords’ key ceremonial and procedural functions while also holding senior roles in government and the legal system. Baroness Boothroyd said the concentration of responsibilities was no longer appropriate, and urged the appointment of a Speaker whose sole focus would be to chair proceedings, uphold standards and represent the Lords independently.

More than 1,000 residents and visitors gathered Sunday in the Nebraska town where television icon Johnny Carson spent much of his youth, offering a hometown farewell to the former “Tonight Show” host. Carson, who fronted the late-night program for three decades, died on Jan. 23 after a long struggle with emphysema, according to family representatives. He moved to Norfolk at age eight and lived there until entering the Navy, but maintained ties for years through frequent visits and charitable giving. The memorial drew former classmates, teachers and community leaders to the Johnny Carson Theater at the local high school. Organizers said Carson had declined a large public service in Los Angeles, where he lived later, preferring that any commemoration be rooted in the community that shaped him. Speakers recalled his early stage appearances as a teenage magician and highlighted donations that helped fund school and arts projects, including a major contribution toward a performing arts facility. National leaders also issued statements praising his impact on American entertainment.

A committee in the European Parliament has called for substantial changes to draft European Union legislation that would define how patents apply to inventions involving software, after lawmakers declined to endorse the latest version. Members of the Legal Affairs Committee said the European Commission should return with a revised proposal, arguing that the text failed to command broad political support and left key questions unresolved. The planned directive is aimed at clarifying whether and when innovations that rely on computer code to deliver a technical effect can qualify for patent protection across the EU, an area where national approaches and court decisions have varied.

The issue has divided industry and lawmakers for years. Critics, including some small technology firms and advocates of open-source development, warn that wider patentability could tilt the market toward large multinationals with extensive legal resources, making it harder for start-ups to innovate without fear of litigation. They also say ambiguous definitions could encourage a surge of broad claims over everyday programming techniques. Proponents, backed by parts of the manufacturing and software sectors, counter that clearer rules would protect genuine research and development, reduce uncertainty for investors and help European companies safeguard products from imitation.

The draft suffered political setbacks in the Council of the EU after Poland and other governments raised objections, prompting renewed debate in several national parliaments and intensifying lobbying from both sides. At the committee session, support for the text was limited, and lawmakers concluded that reopening the process would allow a more comprehensive discussion among member states before any final vote.

Observers frequently point to the United States, where software and certain online business methods can be patented, as a reference point in the debate. Opponents fear Europe could drift toward similarly expansive protections, while supporters insist the EU can craft a distinct, narrower standard.

London’s West End will turn the spotlight on its leading productions and performers on Monday as the Evening Standard Theatre Awards return for a ceremony at the National Theatre. Among the contenders for best musical is Mel Brooks’ The Producers, led by Nathan Lane and Lee Evans, facing competition from revivals including Sweeney Todd and A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum. In the race for best play, judges will choose from a varied shortlist that includes Edward Albee’s The Goat, or Who is Sylvia?, Martin McDonagh’s unsettling drama The Pillowman, and Alan Bennett’s schoolroom comedy The History Boys. The best actress category features Pam Ferris, Victoria Hamilton and Kelly Reilly, with Ferris recognised for her stage performance in Notes on Falling Leaves at the Royal Court, after a career better known to many television viewers. For best actor, Richard Griffiths, who plays teacher Hector in The History Boys, is nominated alongside Douglas Hodge for Dumb Show and Stanley Townsend for Shining City. Directors in contention include Luc Bondy for Cruel and Tender, Simon McBurney for his interpretation of Measure for Measure, and Rufus Norris for Festen, which also appears in the design category. Designers shortlisted range from Ian MacNeil, Jean Kalman and sound specialist Paul Arditti to Hildegard Bechtler for Iphigenia at Aulis and Paul Brown for False Servant. The Milton Shulman Award for outstanding newcomer will go to one of four rising actors: Dominic Cooper, Romola Garai, Eddie Redmayne or Ben Whishaw. Playwrights David Eldridge, Rebecca Lenkiewicz and Owen McCafferty are also in the running for the Charles Wintour Award, which carries a £30,000 bursary. Organisers said three special 50th anniversary honours will be presented during the evening to mark the milestone.

Britain will not reopen talks on its annual EU budget rebate at next week’s European Council meeting, Foreign Secretary Jack Straw has told MPs, insisting the arrangement remains warranted despite renewed calls for reform. Appearing before the Commons foreign affairs committee, Mr Straw said the mechanism—won by Margaret Thatcher in 1984 to offset what the UK argues is an uneven balance between what it pays in and what it receives back—should not be treated as a bargaining chip in discussions on the bloc’s future finances. His remarks follow comments by incoming European Commission president Jose Manuel Barroso, who has floated the idea of redistributing the rebate among member states that are net contributors to the EU budget. Mr Straw said some governments in the enlarged 25-country Union still needed to accept the UK’s case, but added that London’s position was “straightforward” and would not be altered at the summit.

The Brussels gathering, beginning on 16 December, is expected to set the tone for protracted negotiations over the EU’s 2007–2013 spending plans, with diplomats warning that an agreement may not be reached until well into 2005 and possibly later. Several states—including the UK, France, Germany, Austria, the Netherlands and Sweden—are pressing for overall spending to be limited to around 1% of the Union’s combined national income, while the Commission has proposed a higher ceiling of 1.26%. Mr Straw argued that adopting the Commission’s figure would amount to a sharp expansion in EU spending that few national governments could justify domestically.

He also said he hoped leaders could agree a timetable next year to begin membership talks with Turkey, while cautioning that accession itself would remain a distant prospect.

Software developers who distribute programs that covertly monitor activity on personal computers may soon face significant penalties under a new California measure aimed at curbing so-called spyware. The statute, set to take effect on 1 January after being signed by Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger, seeks to reduce unauthorized tracking and limit the theft of personal information by requiring clearer consent and stronger disclosure from companies that install software on users’ machines. Security specialists have warned that spyware is expected to remain a leading irritation and risk for home PC owners, in part because such programs can embed themselves deeply within operating systems and quietly transmit data back to third parties.

At its most damaging, spyware can capture sensitive details including account credentials and payment information, and it may alter browser settings or system controls to make removal difficult. Analysts say newer variants are routinely updated to evade detection, forcing consumers to rely on a mix of anti-spyware tools and frequent security patches. A common subset, often described as ad-supported software, can log browsing habits and trigger persistent pop-up advertising, disrupting normal use and potentially exposing users to further security threats through malicious links.

While lawmakers in Washington have been considering several proposals to address the problem nationwide, California’s action positions the state as an early mover on consumer computer privacy. The law prohibits the installation of software that commandeers a computer without permission and requires businesses to inform users when an application will collect data or change settings. It also allows individuals to pursue damages of up to $1,000 per incident, alongside possible enforcement by state authorities.

The legislation follows broader efforts in California to strengthen privacy protections. Recent industry surveys have suggested that spyware remains widespread on consumer PCs, with many machines carrying multiple hidden trackers. In the absence of clear legal standards, users have increasingly turned to free and commercial anti-spyware programs to detect and remove unwanted software.

General Motors said it expects profit to fall in 2025 compared with last year, pointing to persistent price pressure in the US market and continued restructuring costs in Europe. The automaker said rising expenses tied to employee medical benefits and warranty provisions in North America, along with weaker results at its financing arm, are likely to weigh on full-year performance. Even so, the company said it remains on track to achieve its targets for 2024 when it reports results later this month, citing solid demand for several high-margin models and cost controls implemented in the second half of the year.

GM, which sells vehicles under brands including Chevrolet, GMC and Cadillac in the United States and Opel and Vauxhall in Europe, said it plans to maintain its shareholder return commitments for 2025, with dividends and buybacks broadly in line with the current year. However, it forecast earnings per share next year in a range below 2024 levels, reflecting what executives described as a “highly competitive” environment and the impact of ongoing investments in electrification and software.

Chief executive Mary Barra said management is focused on improving profitability across regions and strengthening free cash flow generation, adding that the company’s long-term financial goals remain unchanged. GM said its European operations should show narrower losses in 2025 as a multi-year efficiency programme continues, including capacity adjustments and headcount reductions concentrated in Germany and the UK.

In other regions, the company reported progress during 2024, including improved margins in Asia-Pacific and a return to profitability in parts of Latin America and the Middle East, helped by new model launches and a more favourable mix of sales. GM’s finance subsidiary, which has been a significant contributor in recent years, is expected to post lower net income in 2025 due to tighter credit conditions and a shift in loan demand. The company reiterated that it is aiming to lift annual earnings materially over the next several years through cost cuts, product upgrades and growth in its services business.

Theo van Gogh’s short film *Submission* has been removed from the programme of the International Film Festival Rotterdam after organisers cited heightened security concerns. The title had been scheduled to screen as part of a freedom-of-speech strand honouring the Dutch director, who was killed in 2004, and was one of three of his works selected for the tribute. The film, made in collaboration with Somali-born Dutch politician Ayaan Hirsi Ali, sparked fierce debate for its depiction of women’s lives under Islam and was widely linked to the threats van Gogh received after it aired on Dutch television. He was shot and stabbed in Amsterdam in November of that year.

Festival officials said the decision to withdraw the film was taken after consultations with authorities and partners, and stressed that the move was based on risk assessment rather than editorial judgement. Two other van Gogh titles remain on the schedule, including the first theatrical screening of his final feature, *06/05*, which examines the killing of politician Pim Fortuyn.

The 10-day festival opens on Wednesday with French documentary-maker Raymond Depardon’s courtroom film *The 10th District Court: Moments of Trials*. Fourteen films are competing for the festival’s Top Tiger prizes, aimed at highlighting emerging directors. New programme sections introduced this year include strands focusing on future-oriented cinema and global filmmaking, with added spotlights on Russian and South-East Asian work. An Iraqi-German production, *Underexposure*, exploring daily life in Iraq after Saddam Hussein, is also among the featured titles.

News Corp, the media group controlled by Rupert Murdoch, is weighing whether to expand into the video games business as it searches for new areas of growth beyond traditional publishing and broadcasting. The Wall Street Journal reported that chief operating officer Peter Chernin told investors the company has been reviewing “a wide range” of game developers and publishers and has held preliminary talks with advisers about possible acquisitions. One company said to have been discussed internally is Los Angeles-area publisher Activision, though no approach has been confirmed and any deal would depend on valuation and strategic fit.

Interest in the sector has been fueled by the continuing rise of console gaming, led by platforms such as Sony’s PlayStation, Microsoft’s Xbox and Nintendo’s GameCube, which have helped push game sales into mainstream entertainment. Modern titles increasingly resemble film productions, with large teams, sophisticated graphics and marketing campaigns that can rival Hollywood releases. As development costs have climbed, publishers have also benefited from higher retail prices and longer-lived franchises, making the business attractive to media companies seeking predictable revenue streams.

Chernin cautioned, however, that finding the right purchase may prove challenging. He said News Corp is trying to navigate between the biggest players—such as Electronic Arts, whose market value is far higher—and smaller studios that may depend heavily on a limited number of brands. Activision’s market capitalization has been estimated at just under $3bn, compared with more than $17bn for Electronic Arts, according to recent market data.

The industry has also been undergoing a wave of consolidation, with major publishers seeking scale to spread development risks and secure access to popular titles. Ubisoft, one of Europe’s largest game makers, has recently taken steps to preserve its independence after Electronic Arts disclosed plans to build a significant stake, prompting analysts to predict further mergers across the sector.

India has reached a long-term energy agreement with Iran valued at about $40bn, committing to purchase several million tonnes a year of liquefied natural gas while also opening the door for Indian companies to invest in upstream projects in the Islamic Republic. Officials said the pact is intended to bolster fuel security as India’s economy expands and domestic output fails to keep pace with demand. The arrangement, announced after meetings in New Delhi that brought together major Middle Eastern producers and leading Asian importers including China, Japan and South Korea, mirrors recent supply-and-investment packages Tehran has been offering to anchor long-term buyers.

Under the outline terms disclosed by the two sides, Iran would begin delivering roughly 7.5 million tonnes of LNG annually over a 25-year period starting in 2009, with pricing and shipping details to be finalised in subsequent contracts. In parallel, a consortium led by state-run Oil & Natural Gas Corporation is expected to pursue participation alongside the National Iranian Oil Company in developing the Yadavaran and Jufeyr oilfields, according to a joint statement.

The announcement came as ONGC indicated it was also exploring acquisitions of overseas assets, including properties formerly linked to Russia’s embattled Yukos. India’s crude production has largely plateaued in recent years, leaving refiners increasingly reliant on imports. Government figures show the country now meets about 70% of its oil needs from abroad, with consumption rising sharply over decades to around 2.4 million barrels per day.

A US public television distributor said it will alter a scene in the BBC Films drama *Dirty War* for its forthcoming broadcast, citing heightened sensitivity among American broadcasters to indecency complaints and potential regulatory repercussions. The film, which portrays a fictional terrorist incident involving radiological material in central London, includes a brief sequence showing a nude female survivor being decontaminated after exposure to chemicals. PBS programming executive Jacoba Atlas said the network considers the moment peripheral to the plot and does not want the broadcast to be derailed by disputes over content. Rather than removing the sequence entirely, PBS plans to substitute alternate footage and adjust camera framing so the decontamination is depicted without an explicit frontal view.

The decision comes as US stations face increased scrutiny over sexual content on free-to-air television. Last year, the Federal Communications Commission imposed a $550,000 fine on CBS after a fleeting onstage exposure involving singer Janet Jackson during the Super Bowl halftime show, a penalty that has prompted many broadcasters to reevaluate standards for nudity, language and graphic imagery. Atlas said airing the unedited film could expose PBS and its member stations to financial and legal risk, and might lead some local outlets to decline the programme altogether. By making limited edits, she said, PBS aims to keep the film available to a wide audience while avoiding content that could trigger formal complaints. The film has previously aired uncut in the UK, and is scheduled to be shown without edits on US cable channel HBO later this month.

The indie comedy-drama *Riverbend* emerged as the top winner at this year’s Independent Spirit Awards, collecting five trophies from five nominations and cementing its status as a late-season awards contender. The film received the night’s top prize for best feature, while filmmaker Lena Hart was honored for best director and shared the best screenplay award with co-writer Daniel Cho. Performances in *Riverbend* were also recognized, with Marcus Peña winning best lead performance and supporting prizes going to Alana Reed and Dominic Shaw. The strong showing comes as the film heads into the Academy Awards with four nominations, adding momentum ahead of Sunday’s ceremony. Now in its 21st year, the Spirit Awards celebrate projects produced outside the major studio system and traditionally take place in the final stretch of the awards calendar. Elsewhere, best actress went to Isabel Rojas for her portrayal of a young paramedic navigating political unrest in the Chilean drama *Night Sirens*, a role that has also earned her an Oscar nomination. The award for best first screenplay was claimed by Priya Nair for *Night Sirens*. Actor-writer-director Eli Barker won best first feature for *Summer Static*. France’s *The Silent Province* took best international film, while the environmental investigation *Tide Line* won best documentary. The honors are determined by members of Film Independent, a voting body made up of actors, directors, writers and other industry professionals. Last year’s Spirit Award leader later converted critical buzz into an Oscar win for original screenplay.

The 1946 holiday classic It’s a Wonderful Life is being developed as a stage musical by producer Jon Thoday, known for backing the boundary-pushing hit Jerry Springer – The Opera. Thoday is partnering with composer and writer Steve Brown, whose previous theatre work includes the award-winning Spend Spend Spend. A representative for the production said the project remains in its early phases, with no casting decisions, venue or premiere date confirmed. Development activity has been underway in London, where workshops have been held to test material, and a small group of performers recently presented songs from the show to invited backers at a private industry event. Thoday said he has wanted to adapt the story for the stage for nearly two decades. The film, directed by Frank Capra and led by James Stewart, was adapted from Philip van Doren Stern’s short story The Greatest Gift. According to the production team, rights to the underlying story were acquired from Stern’s estate before additional agreements were reached to license the film title and elements needed for the musical adaptation.

A senior executive at insurance brokerage Marsh & McLennan has admitted to wrongdoing amid a widening investigation into alleged bid manipulation in the commercial insurance market, according to New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer. The executive, identified by the attorney general’s office as senior vice president Robert Stearns, entered a guilty plea to charges related to a scheme to deceive clients, a case that prosecutors say could result in a prison term ranging from 16 months to four years under state sentencing guidelines. Authorities said Stearns has also agreed to assist investigators and provide testimony in related proceedings as the inquiry continues across the industry.

Marsh, in a brief statement, said it was disappointed by the developments and reiterated that it would continue to work with investigators. The firm added that it intends to address outstanding legal matters and maintain strong compliance practices while continuing to serve clients.

Prosecutors allege that between 2002 and 2004 Stearns directed insurers to submit deliberately uncompetitive quotes in response to client requests for coverage, allowing Marsh to present an appearance of a competitive process while steering business toward a preferred insurer. The attorney general’s office said the alleged conduct enabled the brokerage to influence which carrier ultimately won an account, shielding existing insurers from losing renewals and potentially increasing the brokerage’s compensation.

In one example described by investigators, an internal email allegedly showed Stearns requesting a so-called “B” quote from American International Group that would be priced higher and offer narrower terms, a move prosecutors said was designed to make the incumbent provider, Chubb, appear more attractive.

Marsh continues to face scrutiny from federal regulators as well. The US Securities and Exchange Commission has requested information concerning certain shareholder-related transactions, including dealings involving investors holding at least 5% of the company’s stock, according to people familiar with the matter.

India’s government has cleared the way for privately owned airlines to begin operating long-distance international services, a policy shift intended to expand capacity and put downward pressure on fares as outbound travel grows. Officials said the new permissions would be rolled out in stages, with some high-demand corridors—particularly flights to Gulf destinations such as Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates—remaining reserved for state-run carriers for an initial transition period of up to three years. Industry executives said the first beneficiaries are expected to include Jet Airways and Air Sahara, both of which have built sizable domestic networks that could feed passengers into overseas routes.

The decision comes amid surging demand tied to strong economic growth and rising household incomes. Aviation analysts in Delhi estimate passenger numbers have been climbing at close to one-fifth year-on-year, a pace that has strained airports and air-traffic systems. “The biggest bottleneck is on the ground,” said one observer familiar with the sector, noting that several major gateways still lack modern terminals, adequate baggage handling and sufficient runway capacity for heavier international traffic.

The government has reiterated plans to upgrade and, in some cases, bring in private operators to manage airports, though progress has been uneven. Separately, New Delhi has moved to make the sector more attractive to global partners by increasing the cap on foreign investment in domestic airlines to 49% from 40%. Media reports also say India and the United States may reopen talks early next year on expanding bilateral flight rights.

Tensions between the two prominent heirs of India’s Reliance Group again surfaced this week, this time affecting deliberations at one of the conglomerate’s key subsidiaries. Anil Ambani, vice-chairman of India Petrochemicals Limited (IPCL), did not attend a scheduled meeting of senior executives on Thursday, according to people familiar with the matter. His absence follows his recent attempt to step down from the post, a move that has not been formally accepted by his elder brother Mukesh Ambani, who leads the broader group and also holds ultimate authority at IPCL.

The IPCL board convened in Mumbai to review the company’s performance for the October–December period. Executives said the agenda also included discussion of Anil Ambani’s proposed resignation, with several directors urging him to reconsider. However, the board did not agree to a separate request linked to the dispute: Anil has sought the removal of a fellow director, Anand Jain, whom he has publicly blamed for deepening divisions within the family and influencing decision-making around the brothers.

Anand Jain, regarded in corporate circles as a close associate of Mukesh Ambani, has not commented publicly on the allegations. Company officials declined to discuss internal personnel matters but confirmed that the board had met to approve quarterly disclosures.

In a parallel development, directors at Reliance Energy, another group company headed by Anil Ambani, issued a statement on Wednesday reiterating their support for his leadership. Reliance Group gained control of IPCL in 2002 after purchasing the government’s 26% holding during India’s privatisation programme.

Attention now turns to the flagship Reliance Industries board meeting scheduled for Friday, when quarterly results are due to be considered. With Mukesh serving as chairman and Anil as deputy, the session is expected to bring the brothers into direct contact amid a dispute that has drawn unusually public scrutiny.

Chancellor Rachel Reeves will present the government’s next Budget to the House of Commons on 12 March, the Treasury has confirmed. The statement said the Budget will be delivered at 12:30 GMT, following Prime Minister’s Questions, in keeping with the usual parliamentary timetable. The Budget is expected to provide an updated assessment of the public finances and the wider economic outlook, alongside decisions on taxation, borrowing and spending plans. With a general election widely anticipated later in the spring, the announcement is likely to sharpen political dividing lines over fiscal policy, public services and living costs. Officials noted that the chancellor will also publish the latest forecasts from the independent budget watchdog, setting out projections for growth, inflation and debt. 

If Parliament is dissolved soon after the Budget, ministers may have limited time to legislate for any tax changes through a Finance Bill. In such circumstances, a pared-back bill would typically be fast-tracked with cross-party agreement to ensure the continued legal collection of duties and other revenues. More complex measures are often deferred, with a fuller Finance Bill returning after polling day, depending on the outcome of the election. 

Business groups and tax advisers called for a focus on stability rather than short-term electoral incentives. “Pre-election Budgets can encourage giveaways that are difficult to sustain,” said one senior partner at a major accountancy firm, urging ministers to prioritise predictability for employers and households.

Former Labour MP George Galloway has urged those holding humanitarian worker Margaret Hassan to free her, saying he is ready to assist efforts to secure her release. Mrs Hassan, 59, a senior figure with the aid agency Care International in Iraq, was seized in Baghdad on 19 October and has not been seen in public since. Mr Galloway, who was removed from the Labour Party over his outspoken criticism of the Iraq conflict, made the comments in London during a weekend gathering of delegates from his newly launched Respect coalition.

He rejected reports that he intended to address the kidnappers directly through the Arabic-language broadcaster Al Jazeera, insisting that any involvement on his part would be aimed at helping intermediaries rather than seeking personal exposure. “I have stayed away from previous cases,” he told supporters, adding that Mrs Hassan had long been known for opposing both the war and the years of international sanctions that preceded it. He said he would consider travelling to the region or assisting through contacts if it could help prevent harm.

A spokesperson later said Mr Galloway shared acquaintances with Mrs Hassan and had been approached by people concerned about her safety. Since the abduction, Al Jazeera has aired several recordings of Mrs Hassan, the most recent showing her calling for British forces to leave Iraq and urging her organisation to shut its Baghdad office. Care International has since suspended its remaining work in the country.

IBM said it will invest $120m over the next four years to expand its work with Linux and other open-source tools, aiming to make it simpler for corporate clients to deploy the software across everything from smartphones and tablets to high-end data-center systems. The company said the funding will support engineering, research partnerships and customer outreach designed to improve performance, security and management of Linux-based systems in mixed IT environments. Executives cited rising demand from enterprises looking to standardize their technology stacks while reducing licensing costs and avoiding dependence on a single vendor.

A significant portion of the initiative will focus on collaboration software and device support, IBM said, with new Linux-compatible components planned for its digital workplace offerings. Those products are intended to let employees access business applications, messaging and shared documents regardless of whether they connect through a desktop computer, a thin client or a mobile device. IBM said it plans to enhance tools that help administrators roll out updates and enforce policies across fleets of Linux desktops and handhelds, an area where customers have asked for tighter integration with existing corporate systems.

The company pointed to recent growth in Linux deployments among large organizations, particularly those modernizing internal workflows and moving more applications onto cloud infrastructure. IBM has long backed open-source development, contributing code and staff time to major projects and releasing versions of its software for Linux platforms. Open-source proponents argue that publicly available source code encourages peer review, faster fixes and broader experimentation, benefits IBM said it expects to translate into more reliable products for clients.

Shareholders dissatisfied with Deutsche Boerse’s pursuit of the London Stock Exchange will be unable to force a vote on senior leadership changes before the company’s next annual gathering in late May, according to Reuters. The Sunday Times reported that activist hedge funds TCI and Atticus were preparing to press for the departure of chairman Rolf Breuer and chief executive Werner Seifert, arguing that the bid strategy risks eroding shareholder returns. Deutsche Boerse told Reuters that any formal request to remove members of its supervisory board must be handled at the annual general meeting scheduled for May 25, limiting investors’ ability to accelerate a decision through an earlier vote.

TCI and Atticus have publicly urged the exchange operator to prioritize returning capital to shareholders instead of pursuing a costly takeover campaign. “We are long-term investors and are experienced in removing management. We are not scared to take this to its conclusion this time,” Atticus partner David Slager was quoted as saying by the Sunday Times. The newspaper also said TCI had begun assembling potential candidates to replace the current leadership.

The funds hold a stake of more than 5% in Deutsche Boerse, a level that in many cases can be used to call an extraordinary shareholders’ meeting. Still, under German corporate rules, the company does not require a shareholder vote to make a takeover offer, leaving opponents focused on governance pressure rather than blocking the bid directly.

Deutsche Boerse is competing with pan-European exchange group Euronext for control of the London Stock Exchange, fueling speculation that the contest could escalate into a higher-priced bidding battle. Any rapid developments may be constrained by regulators, with the UK Office of Fair Trading expected to conclude its review of competition issues tied to the rival proposals in March.

France’s financial markets authority has lodged formal complaints against conglomerate Vivendi and two senior executives over a recent convertible bond offering, alleging that investor disclosures may have been insufficient and that managers could have traded while in possession of non-public information. The Autorité des marchés financiers said it has opened proceedings involving the company, its chief executive Jean-René Fourtou and chief operating officer Jean-Bernard Lévy. A complaint was also filed concerning Deutsche Bank, which advised on the transaction and handled placement of the bonds with investors, leaving it potentially exposed to sanctions if the regulator’s claims are substantiated.

According to people familiar with the matter cited by wire services, the regulator is examining whether the prospectus failed to clearly present certain risks and strategic contingencies, and whether the executives had access to sensitive details at the time they purchased portions of the offering themselves. Investigators are reported to be focusing on whether the two men knew of expressions of interest in Vivendi’s U.S. assets from investor Marvin Davis during marketing of the bonds.

Vivendi has denied wrongdoing, saying it considers the complaints unfounded and that relevant information was already in the public domain. The company argues that any approach regarding its American holdings had been discussed openly and, in any case, was not actionable after being turned down by the board.

The AMF is also reviewing claims that management was weighing the possibility of exercising rights to acquire British Telecom’s stake in Cegetel around the same period. Vivendi said such a move was merely one option among several and that markets were aware it could be considered.

The case comes as the French regulator continues to take a hard line on disclosure standards. Vivendi has previously faced penalties from the AMF following an investigation into statements made to investors during a period of aggressive acquisitions.

Postcards created by artists such as Damien Hirst and Tracey Emin were among the first to be snapped up within hours of the opening of the Royal Academy of Arts’ annual Secrets fundraising sale. Buyers do not learn who made a particular work until it has been purchased, when the artist’s name can be found on the reverse. Royal College of Art spokesperson Sue Bradburn said a number of high-profile contributors remained available, including photographer Mario Testino. Each postcard is sold for a fixed price of £35. The event began at 8am on Friday and is due to finish at 6pm on Saturday. Bradburn said the day started with a long line outside the venue, though the crowd had eased later in the morning. She noted that many early purchasers appeared to have arrived with specific targets in mind, spending time carefully comparing the small-format works before choosing. The postcards have been on display for public viewing since 19 November. Contributors this year also include filmmaker Ken Loach, fashion designer Hussein Chalayan and musician Graham Coxon, alongside students and recent graduates from the Royal College of Art and other art schools. Proceeds will support the RCA Fine Art Student Award Fund, which provides bursaries and grants. The sale is in its 11th year.

The global installed base of personal computers is on course to climb sharply over the next several years, reaching about 1.3 billion systems by 2010, according to a new forecast from market researchers at Forrester Research. The firm said the expansion will be fueled primarily by rising demand in developing economies, with countries such as China, India and Russia accounting for more than a third of all additional machines shipped during the period. China alone is projected to add roughly 178 million PCs by 2010, the report estimated, as falling prices and broader internet access bring first-time buyers into the market. Forrester said domestic manufacturers are likely to gain the upper hand in these regions by offering lower-cost models and configurations tailored to local languages, software needs and purchasing power. The outlook arrives days after IBM, long associated with the early PC industry, agreed to sell its personal computer business to Lenovo, China’s largest computer maker, in a transaction valued at $1.75bn (£900m). The combined company is expected to rank as the world’s third-largest PC supplier. “Competitive advantage in emerging markets will increasingly come from local companies that can align design, pricing and applications with regional conditions,” said Simon Yates, a senior Forrester analyst. The study puts the current worldwide PC population at about 575 million units, while predicting more mature markets in the United States, Europe and Asia-Pacific will collectively add around 150 million PCs by 2010. India is forecast to bring in about 80 million new users, with Indonesia adding about 40 million.

Hayao Miyazaki’s newest animated feature, “Howl’s Moving Castle,” will roll out in about 50 markets worldwide, according to its distributor. The film opened strongly in Japan, where it set a new early box-office benchmark by earning roughly 1.5 billion yen in its first weekend. Miyazaki, who won this year’s Academy Award for “Spirited Away,” has drawn renewed international attention to Japanese animation, and the studio expects that momentum to carry into overseas theaters. Adapted from a fantasy novel by British writer Diana Wynne Jones, the story follows a young woman cursed by a witch and transformed into an elderly figure, prompting her to seek refuge in a wandering castle owned by the mysterious wizard Howl as she searches for a way to reverse the spell. A Toho representative said the picture has attracted notable interest from audiences and media abroad. The international release is scheduled to begin with South Korea in late December, followed by France in mid-January.

Madagascar has finalized the transition from the Malagasy franc to the ariary, completing a multi-year overhaul of its monetary system. Beginning Monday, retailers, employers and government agencies must list prices, salaries and official fees exclusively in the new unit, which was quoted at about 1,890 to the US dollar in early trading. The franc has ceased to be legal tender, though the central bank said it can still be exchanged at commercial banks for several years to ease the changeover for households and businesses. Officials said the shift, launched in phases in 2003, is meant to strengthen monetary credibility after a period of sharp depreciation and to curb losses linked to fake notes that had circulated widely. A senior central bank representative described the move as a statement of national autonomy, noting that the name “ariary” revives a traditional term used for money on the island before colonial administration.

The European Parliament has voted down draft legislation that would have expanded the scope for patenting computer-implemented inventions, sending the proposal back to EU institutions for further review. Lawmakers supported a motion to reject the text outright, meaning the measure cannot proceed in its current form and would need to be reintroduced after new consultations if it is to return to the legislative agenda. Supporters of the plan, including several large technology firms and industry groups, argued that clearer patent rules are necessary to encourage investment in research and development and to give European companies confidence that novel software-driven products can be protected from imitation. A spokesperson for a Brussels-based trade association said innovators would be more likely to develop new tools and services if the legal framework offered predictable safeguards for intellectual property. Backers also contended that the EU approach sought to draw boundaries that would prevent the broadest kinds of claims seen elsewhere, where patents may cover certain methods of doing business as well as code-based solutions. Critics, however, warned that the proposal risked granting overly strong rights for ideas implemented in software, potentially enabling litigation-heavy strategies and making it harder for smaller developers to compete. Opponents also said the measure could create legal uncertainty for collaborative development models, including open-source projects, by increasing the likelihood of infringement disputes. The bill had faced repeated setbacks in recent months, including delays linked to objections from some national delegations and calls from parliamentary committees to revise key provisions. Under EU procedures, any future version would still require approval from both the Parliament and a qualified majority of member states before it could become law.

Plans by a major Hollywood studio to depict Dominica’s indigenous Carib community as cannibals in an upcoming instalment of a blockbuster pirate franchise have drawn sharp criticism from the group’s leadership. Carib Chief Marcus Laurent said meetings with representatives of the production team indicated that the screenplay contains “repeated references to cannibalism” that, he was told, are central to the plot and unlikely to be altered. Dominica’s government has confirmed that the film-makers are scouting locations on the island and have expressed interest in shooting several sequences there, citing the island’s rainforest landscape and coastline.

The Caribs, also known as the Kalinago, have long rejected accounts that portray their ancestors as cannibals, arguing the label was used by European colonisers to justify conquest and dispossession. “We resisted invasion, and that resistance was rewritten as barbarity,” Mr Laurent said. “We cannot allow old stereotypes to be recycled for entertainment.”

Filming is expected to begin later this spring, and local casting calls have already attracted large numbers of applicants seeking work as extras, according to officials involved in the preparations. Around 3,000 Kalinago people live in Dominica, which has a population of roughly 70,000, and community representatives say they worry the portrayal could affect how indigenous people are viewed by tourists and the wider public.

Mr Laurent said he has contacted indigenous organisations in the Caribbean and beyond to support an appeal for revisions. He acknowledged, however, that opinion within the community is divided, with some residents favouring the economic boost the production could bring. The studio did not respond to requests for comment.

Fox has begun developing a U.S. drama serial inspired by the BBC soap EastEnders, according to industry reports. Trade publication The Hollywood Reporter said the network has commissioned early scripts and enlisted EastEnders head writer Tony Jordan alongside entertainment entrepreneur Simon Fuller to help shape the adaptation. The proposed series would shift the setting to Chicago, focusing on the intertwined lives of working-class residents in a tight-knit neighborhood. The move comes after the original British program was dropped by BBC America last year following weak audience figures. Previous attempts to translate U.K. hits for American viewers have produced mixed results; NBC’s remake of the BBC comedy Coupling, for instance, was pulled from its prime-time schedule after struggling in the ratings. Meanwhile, EastEnders has faced increased competition in the U.K., with recent viewing figures trailing ITV’s Emmerdale. Executives have shown renewed interest in prime-time soaps in the U.S. after the breakout performance of ABC’s Desperate Housewives, which blended drama with a satirical edge.

Chinese authorities have taken three senior managers from dairy producer Inner Mongolia Yili Industrial Group into custody amid allegations of financial misconduct, according to state media and company disclosures. Yili said its board chairman, chief financial officer and the executive responsible for securities affairs are cooperating with investigators, and the firm has convened a special board session to address governance issues and business continuity. A company representative declined to detail the reasons for the detentions, but Xinhua cited people familiar with the inquiry as saying it centers on suspected misappropriation of corporate funds.  

The detentions come after weeks of market chatter about Yili’s accounting practices and past financing decisions. Several domestic outlets have reported that investigators are reviewing transactions linked to a management-led deal carried out in 2003, including claims that hundreds of millions of yuan were diverted for purposes unrelated to core operations. Yili has not confirmed the amount under review.  

Trading in Yili’s shares was halted after the stock posted a sharp decline earlier in the week, heightening investor unease. The company is one of the largest players in China’s dairy industry, competing with Mengniu Dairy and Bright Dairy in a market that has expanded rapidly as consumer demand for packaged milk has increased. Analysts said the case could prompt closer scrutiny of corporate controls across the sector, particularly among firms that relied on aggressive financing during periods of fast growth.

Bath have brought back former scrum-half Andy Williams on a short-term agreement after securing his release from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. The Wales international, whose deal with the Welsh region was set to run out in June, will remain with the Premiership club until the close of the current campaign. Bath moved quickly to add experience at scrum-half with Martyn Wood sidelined by injury and not expected to return until February, leaving Nick Walshe short of proven cover. Williams said he was keen to seize the chance to rejoin a club he knows well. Capped by Wales against Romania in 2003, he is expected to be considered for selection for Monday’s league fixture away to Sale Sharks. Williams has recently found opportunities limited at the Ospreys, slipping behind New Zealander Jason Spice and with younger options Richie Rees and Rhodri Wells pushing for more game time. Bath director of rugby Jack Rowell said Williams’ recent Heineken Cup and Celtic League involvement made him an ideal fit for the run-in.

A new industry initiative is aiming to help smaller record labels place more of their catalogues on major digital platforms, as music consumption continues to shift toward online purchases. The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) said its research suggests independent releases remain under-represented on many download services, despite strong sales in traditional formats. “Independent music has long performed well in shops, and we want to see it compete on equal terms in digital retail,” said BPI chief executive Peter Jamieson. Digital single sales have now surpassed physical single purchases in the UK, widening the commercial stakes for labels without large marketing budgets. The BPI said it is in talks with leading providers, including iTunes and Napster, encouraging them to improve visibility for independent artists through featured placements and tailored recommendations. The organisation also noted that download purchases are expected to count toward the UK singles chart later this year, a change it described as likely to influence promotion strategies. As part of the programme, the BPI will host workshops for independent companies on distribution, rights management and online marketing. Similar chart rules have already been adopted in the United States.

Chart-leading British pop-rock trio Neon Avenue have confirmed they will pause group activities later this year, easing speculation that the band was preparing to split. In a statement released by their label, Horizon Records, the company said lead singer and guitarist Ryan Cole intends to devote the coming months to writing and touring with his side project, the heavier outfit Northbound. The label added that Neon Avenue members Cole, drummer Liam Hart and bassist Joel Mercer remain committed to returning to the studio “at a later stage”, though no timetable was announced.

Neon Avenue have been a regular fixture on the singles chart since breaking through in 2019, notching seven top-five releases, including three that reached number one. Their best-known tracks include First Period, Satellite Summer, Runaway Vows, Don’t Say Maybe and The Missing Name. The group’s self-titled debut album entered the top 10 on release, and its follow-up, All The Lights On, performed similarly the next year, helping to cement their reputation for bright hooks set against guitar-driven arrangements.

The band collected best pop act at last year’s National Music Awards and were nominated in the British group category. Most recently, they scored another chart-topper with their song Sky Rescue, recorded for the promotional campaign of a new big-screen action remake.

Industry observers have noted the group’s appeal among fans looking for radio-friendly pop that still foregrounds live instruments and songwriting credits. Recent reports had suggested Cole was considering stepping away to focus on Northbound, which is expected to announce tour dates shortly.

Newcastle manager Graeme Souness said he never sensed his side were on the verge of a shock exit as they progressed to the Uefa Cup last 16 after a 2-1 home win over Heerenveen sealed a 4-2 aggregate success. United struck quickly, benefiting from an early own goal before Alan Shearer doubled the advantage with a crisp finish, but the visitors responded after the interval to ensure a tense closing spell. “The first-leg result put us in a strong position,” Souness said. “When you score early it can make players think it’s already settled, and their goal reminded us we still had work to do.”

Shearer’s effort kept him closing in on Jackie Milburn’s long-standing club tally of 200 goals, leaving the striker a dozen short of the landmark. Souness played down suggestions the chase might influence Shearer’s plans, with the captain having indicated he expects to retire at the end of the campaign. “Records are nice, but I don’t think they decide a career,” he said. “If he’s enjoying it and feeling fit, that matters more.”

Souness also singled out winger Laurent Robert for praise, citing his delivery and willingness to drive at defenders as key to Newcastle’s most dangerous passages. “That’s the level we need from him regularly,” the manager added.

French household consumption edged up 1.4% in February, offering a modest boost to hopes of steadier economic momentum, according to data released on Tuesday by the national statistics office. The agency said spending was 3.5% higher than a year earlier, with stronger purchases of home appliances and other durable goods accounting for much of the monthly gain. Consumer prices, meanwhile, slipped 0.4% from January but were 1.7% above their level a year ago, pointing to easing short-term inflation pressures even as annual price growth remained firm. Not all sectors shared in the improvement: registrations of new cars declined 2.5% on the month after a small drop in January, though the market still posted a 6.1% increase compared with February last year. Economists said resilient household demand has been one of the main pillars of recent activity, but cautioned that the outlook remains exposed to external shocks. “Consumption can keep the economy afloat, but the pace is vulnerable to higher borrowing costs and renewed swings in energy prices,” said a Paris-based analyst. In neighboring Italy, a separate survey showed consumer sentiment rising to 104.1 from 103.0, its best reading since late autumn, despite softer expectations for the near term.

A survey of secondary school pupils has found widespread gaps in political awareness among teenagers, with many saying they do not see learning about parties and elections as a priority. In interviews conducted with 120 students aged 14 to 16 for an education report, fewer than one in three correctly identified which party currently leads the government and which forms the main opposition, while a similar proportion were unsure where the third-largest party sits. Most respondents could name the prime minister, but recognition of other senior figures was markedly lower, with fewer than two in 10 able to identify the opposition leader and only around one in 10 recognising the leader of a smaller national party. Several pupils also held mistaken views about which party is in office. The research also explored national identity, finding that the Union flag, traditional meals and familiar sporting events were the most commonly cited markers of Britishness. Many students described themselves primarily by their home nation, and references to a European identity were rare.

The competitive careers of Greek sprinters Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou appear finished, according to the head of the national body that recently dropped domestic disciplinary findings over their alleged failure to attend a doping control. Addressing lawmakers in Athens, Greek Athletics Federation president Vassilli Sevastis said he does not expect either athlete to return to top-level racing, arguing that reputational harm has already undermined their prospects for sponsorship and participation. International officials are now weighing how to respond to the federation’s decision, while the two athletes also face proceedings in Greece’s criminal courts. Prosecutors have filed separate allegations linked to the missed test and claims that a reported motorcycle incident was staged to explain their absence. Sevastis told parliament that material provided by the International Olympic Committee and the sport’s global governing body did not, in his view, meet the threshold required for a guilty verdict under the federation’s procedures. He said the panel was asked to deliver a decisive outcome without being given documentation strong enough to support sanctions. Although the ruling leaves Kenteris and Thanou eligible to enter competitions pending any appeal, Sevastis maintained that further arbitration—even if it overturns the decision—would not restore their standing.

The first U.S. guilty pleas tied to large-scale copyright violations on a peer-to-peer file-sharing system have been entered, federal prosecutors said. Authorities identified the defendants as William Trowbridge of New York and Michael Chicoine of Texas, who admitted to participating in an online scheme that distributed copyrighted music, films and software without permission. The men face potential sentences of up to five years in prison and fines that can reach $250,000, according to the Department of Justice.

In court filings and a statement, prosecutors said the two helped run key “hub” servers used to coordinate a wider sharing community operating on the Direct Connect network, a platform that enables users to exchange files by connecting through centralized directories. Investigators allege the group, described by officials as an organized piracy ring, required members to make substantial collections available to others—ranging from small libraries to massive archives measured in gigabytes—in order to gain access.

Federal agents said they were able to obtain numerous copyrighted works directly from the network as part of the investigation, including feature films, commercial software, video games and music tracks, which officials characterized as evidence of a deliberate operation rather than casual sharing. The case grew out of a series of enforcement actions carried out in August, when the FBI executed search warrants at multiple locations linked to suspected online piracy activity.

The raids were part of an initiative known as Operation Digital Gridlock, aimed at dismantling networks accused of trafficking in pirated digital content. Prosecutors said both men pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit felony copyright infringement, and also acknowledged conduct intended to provide commercial benefit. Sentencing is scheduled for 29 April.

Climate change risks accelerating beyond manageable limits within the next few decades, Scotland’s environmental regulator has told MSPs as part of a parliamentary inquiry into the country’s readiness for a warmer, more volatile climate. Giving evidence to Holyrood’s environment committee, officials from the Scottish Environment Protection Agency said emissions from transport and energy continue to rise, and warned that existing policies may not cut greenhouse gases quickly enough. Witnesses argued that Scotland will likely need a mix of measures, including rapid expansion of renewable generation and continued use of low‑carbon baseload power, while broader efforts to curb demand are scaled up. 

Several contributors to the session said large onshore wind developments could become more common, bringing visible changes to rural landscapes, while investment in grid upgrades and storage would be required to maintain reliability. Others urged ministers to focus on reducing aviation within the UK and shifting more journeys onto electrified rail services, alongside cleaner buses and support for active travel. 

The committee also heard fresh analysis from marine researchers monitoring the Atlantic approaches to Scotland, who reported signs that severe weather could become more frequent and more damaging. Scientists involved in a multi‑institution study have been examining wave patterns and storm surges using satellite observations and buoy data collected over recent years, with a focus on the waters off the west coast and around the Hebrides. They told MSPs the findings align with projections of higher seas and stronger storms, increasing risks to coastal communities, infrastructure and fisheries.

Jennifer Lopez and her husband, singer Marc Anthony, are expected to share the stage for a joint performance at this month’s Grammy Awards in Los Angeles, organisers have confirmed. The couple, who married in 2004, will appear together during the 13 February broadcast in a duet that is already drawing attention as one of the night’s headline moments. Anthony, a Grammy winner with a long track record in Latin music, arrives at this year’s ceremony with multiple nominations, including recognition in Latin pop and tropical categories.

The show will also feature a special all-star version of The Beatles’ “Across the Universe,” performed by Bono, Stevie Wonder, Norah Jones and Brian Wilson, as part of a fundraising effort for victims of the Indian Ocean tsunami. A studio version of the track, which also includes contributions from Alicia Keys, Velvet Revolver and Tim McGraw, will be made available for purchase online, with proceeds directed toward relief initiatives. Fans will be able to buy the song through iTunes and access a companion video through CBS’s website.

Beyond the tribute, the telecast is set to include appearances by U2, Green Day, Keys and rapper Kanye West, who leads this year’s nominations with 10. West is slated to perform with John Legend, Mavis Staples and the Blind Boys of Alabama. The programme will also honour the late Ray Charles, who has several posthumous nominations, with a tribute segment featuring artists including Bonnie Raitt and Billy Preston, alongside a separate celebration of southern rock bringing together McGraw, Gretchen Wilson and members of Lynyrd Skynyrd.

Second seed Joachim Johansson claimed the Australian Hardcourt Championships in Adelaide on Sunday, defeating American Taylor Dent 7-5 6-3 to secure the second title of his professional career. The Swede was tested early as Dent fought off several chances to drop serve, saving three break points in a tense fifth game that kept the opening set on a knife edge. Johansson eventually found the decisive opening late in the set with an aggressive return that swung momentum, then tightened his baseline play to pull clear in the second. The victory follows his breakthrough tournament win in Memphis in 2004, a result that helped propel him from outside the top 100 into the upper tier of the rankings. Dent, despite the loss, said Johansson’s power game made him a serious threat for the Australian Open, which begins on 17 January, pointing in particular to his serving accuracy. Johansson said he was encouraged by his form but insisted he needed further improvements in Melbourne.

Elena Dementieva defeated defending champion Venus Williams 6-3 6-2 on Sunday to capture the Champions Challenge exhibition title in Hong Kong. The sixth-ranked Russian took control early at Victoria Park, converting three breaks of serve in the opening set and limiting Williams’ opportunities on return. Williams briefly threatened a comeback by fighting off three match points, but Dementieva closed out the contest with steady baseline play and consistent serving. “It’s a positive way to begin the season, even if it’s not part of the regular tour,” Dementieva said, adding that the win would boost her confidence heading into the year’s major tournaments. Williams, 24, said she was frustrated by her level, citing a high number of unforced errors at key moments. Prior to the final, tournament officials held a charity auction of player racquets, raising about £115,000 for tsunami relief efforts.

The Manhattan recording complex where John Lennon worked on some of his last sessions is set to shut its doors in the coming weeks, marking the end of an era for one of New York’s best-known studios. The Hit Factory, a fixture of the city’s music scene for decades, built its reputation by hosting major acts across pop, rock and hip-hop, but operators say changing technology and shifting client demand have made the large facility increasingly difficult to sustain. The company plans to move operations to a smaller location in Miami, reflecting an industry-wide drift toward compact rooms and home-based production.

Lennon is among the studio’s most closely associated artists, having recorded material there for his comeback album “Double Fantasy” in the late 1970s. Founded in 1968 by songwriter and producer Jerry Ragovoy, the business later changed hands and expanded under producer Edward Germano into a multi-room complex offering recording, mixing and mastering services under one roof. Early sessions included work by Stevie Wonder, and the studio’s credits grew to encompass landmark projects such as Bruce Springsteen’s “Born in the U.S.A.,” the Rolling Stones’ “Emotional Rescue,” and Paul Simon’s “Graceland.” Over the years, artists ranging from Madonna and David Bowie to Jay-Z and Beyoncé booked time at the facility. In the mid-1990s, the studio reached a high-water mark when recordings completed there were linked to dozens of Grammy nominations in a single year, including music from “The Bodyguard” soundtrack.

EuroDisney, the Paris-area theme park operator, announced plans on Tuesday to raise about 255 million euros through a new share issue as it seeks to avert a cash crisis and complete a broader overhaul of its balance sheet. The offering forms the final stage of a debt restructuring aimed at addressing roughly 2.4 billion euros in liabilities accumulated since the resort opened in the early 1990s. Management said recent operating trends have improved, citing firmer attendance and higher ticket revenue, but market watchers remain cautious about whether the resort can sustain profitability once the refinancing measures are in place. The complex is still regarded as Europe’s biggest single tourist draw, with annual visitor numbers around 12 million, and has been expanding its entertainment lineup with a recently launched studio-themed park next to the main site. Shares in the company fell sharply in Paris trading following the announcement, as investors reacted to the dilution implied by the low offer price. The new stock will be taken up by the group’s two leading investors, including the US-based Disney parent and a Middle Eastern partner, according to the company.

A low-budget drama featuring actor Mark Ruffalo as a recently released sex offender took the festival’s top prize at the Edinburgh International Film Festival on Saturday, prompting debate over the decision. The film, titled *Second Chances*, received the Caledonia Grand Award, an honour named for pioneering Scottish filmmaker John Grierson. Directed by first-time feature director Lena Whitaker, the story follows a man attempting to re-enter society after a long prison sentence, while facing public hostility and strict supervision. In a statement, the jury said the film confronted a difficult subject with restraint and careful attention to the impact on victims and the wider community. Past recipients of the award include several titles that later found wider acclaim on the international circuit.

The festival also recognised emerging home-grown talent, presenting its UK New Voices prize to writer-director Saira Mahmood for her debut *Harbour Street*, set in Newcastle and centred on a young mother drawn into an escalating dispute with her immigrant neighbours. Separate honours from the International Critics’ Panel went to *Glass Steps*, a French-Belgian feature about disability and independence, while the festival’s first-film trophy was awarded to Canadian filmmaker Eli Navarro for the autobiographical collage *Static Days*.

The event concluded with a gala screening of the ensemble comedy *The Existentialists*, starring Paul Rudd and Frances McDormand, directed by indie veteran Martin Keene. This year’s line-up also included an early European showing of the latest animation from Studio Lumi and the UK premiere of the urban drama *Southside Boys*.
